Under proper regulations they ought frequently to be referred to, ſo far, I mean, as is neceſſary to point out the errors which prove fatal to the happineſs of numbers, that young ladies may know, before they engage in the moſt important connections of life, the danger of improper conduct; and be qualified when they have an opportunity of marrying with a good proſpect, and the full conſent of their friends, to make a "well ordered home, their huſbands beſt delight."To inſtruct their children, govern their ſervants, and regulate their expences; inſtead of fancying, as is too frequently the caſe with the modern fair, that when they leave ſchool they have nothing to do but to diſplay their beauty and accompliſhments, to adorn their perſons, in order to gain admiration, and to run the giddy round of inceſſant amuſement. Wretched muſt be the man who calls ſuch an one his wiſe! miſerable the lot of her neglected children ••

div.head: THE TRIUMPH OF REASON, A DRAMA, IN THREE ACTS.
SCENE, a Parlour.
div.stage: [Miſs Clara Freeman fitting at work, enter Miſs Freeman in great haſte.]

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: O, SISTER, you are here! I have been ſeeking you this half hour, that we might be together when the mantua-maker comes to try on our new dreſſes.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I am at preſent very buſy in making the children's things.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: That is an employment in which you will never receive any aſſiſtance from me; I ſhould not have thought of troubling myſelf about a parcel of tireſome bra • s.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: You were once a little brat, as you call it, yourſelf; what would have become of you if every body had been of your opinion?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p:
O, but I was the eldeſt, and a rarity—and had people
now to wait upon me? and ſo ought my brothers and ſiſters to have—for mamma cannot reaſonably expect that I ſhould throw my time away upon them.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: And yet, how do we in all companies hear Miſs True-worth praiſed; becauſe ſhe takes ſo much pains with her brothers and ſiſters, and teaches them every thing they learn?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: That may do very well for her, who has no great fortune to boaſt of—but my papa, though he is a tradeſman, has money enough for a lord; and my aunt told me, he could make us as rich as ladies.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: It may be ſo, but mamma teaches a different leſſon; ſhe ſays, we had better be good than great, and that humility is a moſt amiable virtue.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Do you know the reaſon of that? becauſe ſhe herſelf had no fortune, but was a pennyleſs colonel's daughter, and, therefore, as my aunt told me, ſhe deſpiſes money.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I am ſure mamma is the moſt agreeable woman I ever ſaw. She is ſo gentle and kind to every one, I think it very ſtrange that my aunt ſhould have ſpoken againſt her, and to her own child too!

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I do not ſee much harm in what my aunt ſaid. When my papa conſented to my living with her, ſhe endeavoured to eradicate many ſentiments which differed from her own; It was natural for her to try to perſuade me to think like herſelf.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p:
Perhaps • o. But I know your going to live with her was contrary to mamma's inclination, and 〈◊〉 have often ſeen her 〈◊〉
• ears about it.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p:
I am only ſorry my poor aunt died, which obliged me
to return home, for I ſhall never be ſo happy again as I was with her. Mamma confines me and will not let me have a variety of fine cloaths. I was forced to get at papa alone, and coax him to conſent to our going to Monſieur De Fierville's ball, and to allow us new dreſſes for the occaſion; and I can perceive that mamma is diſpleaſed becauſe I have gained my point.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Fie! Matilda, you accuſe my dear mother very wrongfully; indeed ſhe is delighted to give us pleaſure under proper reſtrictions; and ſurely ſhe muſt be a better judge of propriety than either you or I can pretend to be.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Perhaps ſo; but her notions are very ſtrange. The other day ſhe chid me for not giving Mrs. Molly, the houſemaid an anſwer. Why, I cannot think there is any neceſſity for ſhewing civility to ſuch ſort of people.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: And I ſhould be aſhamed of treating them otherwiſe than civilly. Whilſt they do their duty, they have a right to our regard; and the beſt method of inſuring reſpect from them, is ſetting a good example, which cannot be done without feeling both for them and ourſelves.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Well, I always treated my aunt's ſervants juſt as I pleaſed, and they were forced to ſubmit to it: ſom times I made them play with me, and at other times, uſed them as ill as ever I could.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I ſhould be aſhamed, even if mamma permitted it, to act ſo by any body inferior to me; if they are honeſt, they are as good as I am, and much more neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: So are the cat and the dog, I conſider them all on a footing.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p:
Chriſtians to be looked on in ſuch a light! indeed ſiſter,
you ſhock me. I never made companions of the ſervants; but if they behaved well, always thought them full as worthy as myſelf.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: So do not I: but you have no ſpirit. I ſuppoſe, the other afternoon, you would have ſubmitted to Miſs Foley's • itting above us; yet I ſoon ſent the lady • o her proper ſtation.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: To confeſs the truth, I never was ſo much confuſed in my life as at your conduct on that occaſion; for I am ſure, Harriet Foley would not for the world, be guilty of rudeneſs to any one.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: What buſineſs had ſhe to ſet herſelf above me? I ſhall always act ſo by every body I think beneath me.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Mamma ſets us a very different example; and yet ſhe is every where treated with great reſpect.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: To be ſure does not money make the man; and has not mamma an elegant coach, a great houſe and riches enough to outdo moſt of her neighbours?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: But ſhe does not plume herſelf upon theſe advantages. You know, "the humble ſhall be exalted."

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: And "the exalted may be abaſed for me." I ſhall never think of ſuch precepts while I am rich, poor I cannot be; for I know my aunt left me handſomely.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I never heard ſo much about rickes before; my mamma has always armed my mind to bear a reverſe of fortune, and I think papa muſt have had great loſſes lately, or he would not have diſcharged ſeveral ſervants, and given up his houſe in the country.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p:
It will be horrid indeed, if he reduces his circumſtances;
though it will not trouble me, for he muſt always ſupport me as I have been uſed to live; I cannot ſubmit to a reverſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: It would be a great ſhame if we murmured at any employment which my mamma ſets us the example of. To ſave her trouble, I offered to make theſe frocks, as the maid, who uſed to work for the children, is one of thoſe who are diſcharged.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: One comfort is, I do not know how either to make or mend, and I am not ambitious of learning, believe me.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I never ſaw my mamma at ſuch employment till very lately, yet ſhe does it with as much cheerfulneſs as embroidery, or any other fancy work.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: To tell you the truth, I hate work, nor will I do any. My aunt never made me, and why ſhould any other perſon?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: And I cannot bear idleneſs. My mamma's example has taught me to love employment, and I am by that means, free from the danger of having my time ever hang heavily on my hands.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I have found time ſadly heavy ſince my return home, but never did ſo at my aunt's; for there I uſed, when tired of the parlour, to go into the kitchen, or garden, and make the ſervants romp with me; but now it is in vain to ſpeak to a domeſtic, for they have orders not to hold converſation, or be more with me than their buſineſs requires, on pain of loſing their places.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p:
You waſted time in paſſing it ſo unprofitably; the attention to my education, mamma's converſation, and playing with the little ones, fills up all my hours without leaving a moment to ſpare. Apropos, have you ſeen the
fan mounts I painted, let me ſhew them to you.
sp.stage: [She takes them from a large port folio, and ſpreads them on the table.]

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: They look pretty; but I do not underſtand any thing about painting, nor can I diſcover what uſe there is in young ladies of fortune knowing how to draw.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: It is the pleaſanteſt employment imaginable, and aſſiſts us in diſcerning the bountiful goodneſs of our Creator, who gave us ſuch beautiful flowers and plants to gratify our ſenſes of ſeeing and ſmelling.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I do not like flowers, and therefore never regard them; indeed, the very ſweet ones make me faint.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: There are ſome too powerfully fragrant for a room, but in the open air their odours are delightful.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: You talk very affectedly on this ſubject, I think; pray who taught you?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: My ever dear mamma, ſhe is never tired of ſtudying the beauties of nature, nor I of being inſtructed by her.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: But you cannot paint from the flowers?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Yes, I do; and am ſo entertained, that it is with regret I leave off. Try to draw, ſiſter, and you will be as fond of it as I am.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I could never diſcover one charm in any thing that required taking pains, and ſhall not begin now. I had maſters, but would not attend to them.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: My mamma was my inſtructreſs: perhaps, had you been taught by her, your averſion to learning would have ceaſed.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I believe not. For with all mamma's hoaſted cleverneſs, I cannot ſuppoſe her quite ſo capable of teaching as maſters are who gain their livelihood by it.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: She might not be more capable, but I ſee no reaſon to doubt her being on an equality with them; what one perſon can learn, another may; and it is viſible that my mamma is elegantly accompliſhed, though ſhe only ſhews it for the advantage of her children.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: From whence you infer, that you are as clever as any young lady can be.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: You pervert my meaning ſtrangely, Matilda. I hope I am not ſo conceited; but if my capacity is a good one, I ſee no reaſon why I may not improve as well under my mamma's tuition as under any maſter's whatever.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Mamma has done one thing to gratify herſelf, ſhe has taught you to have as high an opinion of her cleverneſs as ſhe has; my aunt inſtructed me otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: We ſeem to differ on a very material point, and therefore had better never mention it again. I reverence my mother, ſhe is kindneſs itſelf; I never yet ſaw any perſon equal to her; but that probably i • owing to my not having opportunity of obſerving other people's actions • o clearly as I do her's. Her mind is compoſed of gentleneſs, charity, and humanity.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: You are quite in heroics; and had better write a poem in praiſe of her.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: If I were capable, I could not chuſe a more pleaſing ſubject.

div.stage: [Enter Mary.]

sp.speaker: MARY.
sp.p: The mantua-maker is come, ladies, and begs to know if you are ready to have your cl •• ths fitted?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Ready! She has kept me waiting for her theſe two hours—order her to walk in.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Pray, ſiſter, do not ſhew any diſpleaſure to poor Mrs. Ga • es. Conſider ſhe was once a gentlewoman, and that ſhe is now deſirous to oblige every body.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: And is that a reaſon I am to be confined here attending her leiſure. I ſhall tell her my mind indeed.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Let me entreat you to have more compaſſion. If ſhe is wrong, it is mamma's place to reprove her, and not ours.

div.stage: [Enter Mrs. Gates.]

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN, [to her ſiſter.]
sp.p: I tell you I will not be controlled.—A fine time you have made us wait, madam; you did not dare do ſo at my aunt's, ſhe would ſoon have turned you off if you had.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GATES.
sp.p: I was detained at Lady Jenkins's longer than I expected; her ladyſhip was kind enough to beg of me, as a favor, to ſtay half an hour for her; how then could I refuſe? Yet I beg your pardon, ladies, if it has materially interfered with your employment, I am ſincerely ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Miſs;FREEMAN.
sp.p: And what compenſation is begging our pardon? I inſiſt on its never happening again. Have not you prepared my dreſs for putting on. Prithee, hurry yourſelf a little more.
Mrs. Gates puts it on, and takes great pains to make it ſet neatly.]

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: How horribly it is made—no taſte—the train is frightful. I wiſh mamma had been perſuaded. I did all I could to have a better mantua-maker.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GATES.
sp.p:
I have taken a deal of pains to make it faſhionable; and Lady Mary Bennet
〈…〉 the one ſhe wore at the Feſ • ino, as a pattern.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Perhaps you have made it as well as you could, but it is ſecond hand work, in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GATES,
sp.p: Do you think it wants any improvement, madam?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I am not ſufficiently accuſtomed to faſhionable dreſs to be a competent judge; but it appears, in my eyes, very complete indeed. However, my mamma is the propereſt perſon to determine, and ſhe is in her dreſſing room: had you not better go to her, Matilda?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe I muſt. But my opinion of her taſte does not exceed that of Mrs. Gates's; for how ſhould ſhe know faſhions, who goes ſo ſeldom to public places?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GATES.
sp.p: Shall I have the honor of fitting your dreſs now?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Mrs. Gates. I do not mean to detain you, but I am afraid you are fatigued, had you not better reſt yourſelf firſt?—pray ſit down;—nay, I inſiſt upon it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GATES.
sp.p: Your goodneſs, worthy young lady, oppreſſes me. I really am not fatigued, or I would avail myſelf of your kind attention to me.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: We will, then, begin as ſoon as you pleaſe. [She puts on her new dreſs.] It appears to ſit extremely well, and is neatly and elegantly made; yet this ſleeve is ſomewhat too large, do you not think ſo?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GATES.
sp.p:
I think it is, and will take care to alter it. Indeed, Miſs Clara, I have a pleaſure in working for you; but
your ſiſter treats me with ſuch haughtineſs, that I am ſometimes tempted to give up attending her, and but for your obliging behaviour to me I certainly ſhould do ſo.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: If you knew my ſiſter better, your opinion of her would alter; ſhe does not mean to wound you, it is only her manner. I will juſt go and take my mamma's opinion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Good morning to you, Mrs. Gates, I hope you are well? have you reſted a little? for I know you take long walks.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GATES.
sp.p: It would ill become one, in my reduced circumſtances; madam, and with a young family, to indulge in a coach hire. I am thankful that I can maintain myſelf and little ones, without being burthenſome to any one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Honeſt induſtry ſeldom wants encouragement. I am glad you have employment enough to gratify your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GATES.
sp.p: You are all goodneſs, madam; but your kind condeſcenſion is ſhewn to one, who is grateful for your favors. Do you approve of the young ladies cloaths?

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Very much, Matilda's only wants the train to flow more behind; and Clara's to be made narrower in the back.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GATES.
sp.p: I will be attentive to your commands.
sp.stage: [She aſſiſts in taking off their things.]

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN, [impatiently.]
sp.p: Do not pull off my arms, woman. How a • kward you are; there, get away, or you will take part of me.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: There is a pin in the way, I will be obliged to you to remove it,—thank you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GATES.
sp.stage: [Takes up her parcel, and makes a reſpectful curteſy.]
sp.p: Ladies your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Good morning to you.

stage.p: [Miſs Clara curteſies to her. She goes out.]

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN, [Burſting into a loud laugh.]
sp.p: Are you practiſing, Clara? for you could not have made a finer obeiſance to the QUEEN.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I was not conſcious of any thing ridiculous, ſiſter, but am glad to ſee you ſo merry.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Merry! why who can help being diverted at ſeeing you ſo mighty complaiſant to that woman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Is an act of common civility ſo very extraordinary then?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: But to a mantua-maker, madam! why, ſhe will thank the ſervants by-and-by for doing their duty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: I hope ſo. She will at leaſt treat them with kindneſs; even ſervants may behave ſo as to deſerve thanks. If Matilda acts properly, the advantage will be her own; for, giving encouragement where it is due, ſecure her reſpect. But in this inſtance, the heart muſt be ill formed that could lead any one to forget the miſfortunes which reduced poor Mrs. Gates to her preſent ſituation: yet, while we pity her diſtreſs we muſt honor the fortitude that has ſet her above it, and made her prefer gaining her bread by virtuous induſtry, to becoming the flatterer of empty pride with a view of gaining a livelihood among the great.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I do not comprehend your meaning, mamma; but think it very ſtrange, to prefer acquiring one's livelihood by work, to a ſituation that ſets one above being looked upon in ſo mean a light.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: You do indeed ſtrangely miſtake the matter, my dear Matilda, to think ſtooping to dependence leſs mean, than engaging in an honeſt employment. All good people eſteem Mrs. Gates highly, and honor the laudable pride that has raiſed her above her miſfortunes. There are two kinds of pride, the falſe and the proper; nor can I deſcribe them better than by aſſuring you, that ſhe poſſeſſes the right, and you the wrong.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Why am I to blame for not working, when there is no occaſion for me to do it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: At leaſt you are to blame, for deſpiſing, and treating with hautineſs, a worthy amiable woman, only becauſe ſhe makes your gowns. A woman who was better born and as well educated as yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: My aunt always judged as I do. She never liked any body that was poor, becauſe ſhe thought them mean.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Meanneſs is not a neceſſary attendant on poverty. Your aunt is dead, and her faults ought to be buried in oblivion. Truly am I concerned, that through the narrowneſs of her mind, ſhe has ſo greatly contracted your's: yet, I hope, precept and obſervation, will overcome the prejudices of education.—Would your father's becoming poor make me leſs a gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I do not know.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p:
Then you doubt. Let me, therefore, endeavour to convince your reaſon, by relating two examples of people perſonality known to you. To begin with Mrs. Gates, her huſband was a gentleman of fortune but unhappily fond of ſhew and parade; he lived to ſquander away his whole eſtate, among people who only deſpiſed, though they aſſiſted to ruin him; as his death ſhe was left deſtitute with three
young children. All her acquaintance of high rank forſook her; ſome few friends remained, but they were ſuch as you would call mean, becauſe they were not rich. Theſe ſolicited relief for her, from her huſband's former intimates. They all turned a deaf ear, except one great lady, who offered to give her the run of her houſe, that is to feed her; in return for which, ſhe was to flatter her abſurdities, and even her vices. Her children were to be put out to ſervice as they grew up. Mrs. Gates deſpiſed the offer and the offerer; and with the advice and recommendation of her more humble friends, ſhe undertook her preſent employment, in which ſhe has happily ſucceeded, and is regarded, and reſpected by the good, whether of high or low degree. Mrs. Combs, who you know lives with Lady Harris, was reduced alſo by the extravagance of others; yet rather than undertake any thing like work, ſhe ſubmitted to become her ladyſhip's humble friend. You have often remarked the cruel treatment ſhe receives even before us, who viſit Lady Harris, merely on a footing of formality. Now tell me, Matilda, which of theſe two perſons is the moſt reſpectable character and poſſeſſes the propereſt pride?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: As you relate it, Mrs. Gates is undoubtedly the beſt, and the happieſt. But if my papa were to loſe his fortune, I do not know what would become of me, for I am certain I could not follow her example.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p:
It cannot be pleaſing to you young as you are, to dwell upon ſuch a thought. Yet [
•• ghs] it is a miſfortune very likely to happen. Your papa carries on an extenſive trade, and his ſucceſs depends more frequently on others, or even on the uncertain elements, than on himſelf. It is therefore the duty of all connected with him to a • m their minds for a reverſe; and I would wiſh you to conſider things in a proper light, that you may be ſtrengthened to ſupport a miſfortune, which it will probably be your portion to bear.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I ſhall always have my aunt's fortune; that, the ſervants aſſured me ſhe had left entirely to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN,
sp.p:
Dear girl, how you diſtreſs me! ſo young, and yet ſo
•• ger after fortune▪ with pain to myſelf muſt I undeceive you. Your aunt had nothing to leave; ſhe lived on an annuity which ceaſed with her life; a few ornaments were all ſhe had to bequeath, and thoſe are your's.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p:
Well, I cannot believe that papa will ever make himſelf
〈◊〉 ; and I hope, mamma, I am to wear all my new things at the 〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: I have not thought about it yet. But depend on it, if you go, you ſhall be dreſſed properly.—Clara, you work very hard; your aſſiſtance relieves and obliges me, my dear girl. If your father and I were reduced to poverty, what would you do to aſſiſt us, and your brothers and ſiſters?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I would work for you, and paint ſcreens and fanmounts, and embroider-muffs and waiſtcoats, and would give you all the the money I acquired.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: I thought ſo. Well, my beloved girls, we muſt hope for the •• ſt, and may GOD direct us, if called to ſo ſevere a trial! your talents, if not requiſite to aſſiſt, will always be a ſure refuge to yourſelves, from the wearineſs of ſolitude, and make you never leſs alone, than when alone. But I muſt not ſpend any more time in talking with you at preſent. When you wiſh to ſee me, you will find me in my dreſſing room.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA
sp.p: I am certain, mamma, is extremely unhappy; what will become of me, if I ſee my parents in diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: It is time enough to think of it when it happens. You will be a pretty figure for the ball to-morrow night, with a crying countenance!

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I ſhall not be much diſpoſed for merriment, unleſs I ſee a viſible alteration in mamma. It is a great comfort though, that I can earn money, if miſfortunes ſhould happen, how much you will, Matilda, lament the neglect of your education!

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Do not talk of it. I ſhall never dare to look the young ladies in the face to whom I have behaved ſo haughtily, they will exult in my loſing what I valued myſelf upon.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Make it a leſſon then in future, to ſtudy how to bear a fall, and believe an affectionate ſiſter, that you never appear ſo unpleaſing as when you behave proudly.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: The example is ſet me, by almoſt all my acquaintance; and why am I to be different from the reſt of the world?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Did you ever think a haughty behaviour appeared amiable in any one perſon? I cannot think who you have aſſociated with; I ſee but few ſuch char • cters among my acquaintances.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I never conſidered it. But I had no notion of giving up to people no better than myſelf.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I am not equal to holding an argument on this ſubject; my mamma, will, no doubt, tell you her ſentiments, as ſhe has me; and ſoon convince you, that you will ſhew more good ſenſe by ſubmitting to others, than by contending. I have done my work now, and will carry it into the nurſery. Shall we go together?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: With all my heart. I can play with the children, though I will not work for them.

div.head: SCENE, A Dreſſing Room.
div.stage: Mrs. Freeman alone, in a very diſconſolate poſture. After a time, ſhe ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: WHY cannot I raiſe my mind above the anxiety of the preſent moment? If poor Mr. Freeman's late loſſes are as great as he apprehends, I know the worſt that can happen; with patience will I ſubmit, even to the loweſt humiliation, for his, and my children's • ake, and it is for them, more than for myſelf, I grieve.

div.stage: [Enter a Servant.]

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Mrs. Allworthy is below, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Deſire her to walk up. I do not ſtand on ceremony with her.
Good creature! report has conveyed the news of our misfortunes to her ears, and ſhe is come to conſole me.

div.stage: [Enter Mrs. Allworthy.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: How are you, my deer madam? I hope my company is not an intruſion?

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Far from it, madam: ſuch a friend as Mrs. Allworthy, is always welcome. Nor would you have talked of intruſion, had not rumour been already buſy, and informed you—ſomething diſquiets me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p:
I have heard more than I hope is true. To aſſiſt you
as far as I have power brought me hither. Though your own excellent judgment will direct you better than I can do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: I have nothing to reſolve on but ſubmiſſion. We know not the extent of our lo • ies. Mr. Freeman went immediately after dinner to make perſonal enquiries about his property, which now hangs on ſo ſlender a twig, as our ſhips, uninſured, eſcaping a hurricane which has happened in the Weſt-Indies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Then you have ſtill the ſupport of hope; and even ſhould the worſt happen, Mr. Freeman has ſo active a mind, that he will never reſt until he is in a ſituation to retrieve his loſſes, and regain his fortune.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: You comfort me agreeably. And, indeed, I believe he will purſue fortune, as long as life is ſpared. Men in buſineſs, with active minds, ſeldom give up. I know too well the value of money to deſpiſe it. But believe me, my concern is not for myſelf; I ſee too many inſtances of happineſs, with a modern competency, not to be perfectly content with it, if that remains.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Are your daughters acquainted with your preſent diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Not thoroughly. Yet my dear Clara gueſſes a great deal from my looks; her attention to which diſcovers more, than I wiſh her to know.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: And why not inform them? they are of an age to be your comforters, and may, if neceſſary, contribute to your ſupport.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p:
I have no reaſon to doubt the goodneſs of their hearts. Matilda indeed has imbibed opinions I wiſh to alter; and perhaps this early rub in life, may aſſiſt to refine a mind
that has been led wrong by one whom ſhe was taught to reverence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Under your management I doubt not its proving to her advantage; and as ſhe is not deficient in underſtanding, your endeavours will reconcile her to that which is right.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Poor girl! ſhe will be ſadly chagrined at her not going to her dancing maſter's • all to-morrow night. I dread diſappointing her; yet in our preſent ſituation, it would be exceedingly improper to permit my daughters to go to a place of public entertainment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Certainly. Command me as an aſſiſtant on this unpleaſant occaſion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: They will come with the tea. I was unable to attend as uſual to my little ones, and deſired your god-daughter to hear them their leſſons. Matilda, had no occaſion for having an employment given her; the milliner and mantua-maker, had juſt ſent home her new dreſs and ornaments for the b • ll, and I could not draw her from the admiration of them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: I pity her diſappointment, while I feel the neceſſity of it, and think the preſent pain may prove in the event a ſource of real joy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: My prayers will be ſincere for this bleſſed effect! had I placed my dependence on what her infatuated aunt taught her to do, deſpondence and horror would now have been my lot.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p:
How cruel are thoſe parents who lead their children on in unthinking ſecurity? Never taught to look beyond the preſent moment, or to obſerve the changes which ſo frequently happen in this fluctuating world, the bitter
pangs of diſappointment come ſuddenly upon them, and their unprepared minds ſink under miſfortunes, that did they but know how to receive them properly, might in the end turn to bleſſings, by giving them an opportunity of ſubmitting, as their duty requires, to the decrees of an all-wiſe Providence, who never fails to comfort thoſe who reſign themſelves to his will.

div.stage: [Enter Footman, and places the tea things.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Let Miſs Freeman and Miſs Clara know that tea is ready.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: O! my overcharged heart! [burſts into tears.] This is a relief I greatly ſtood in need of, and will, I truſt, enable me to perform my duty, in ſetting an example to my children.

div.stage: [Enter Miſs Clara.]

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I have very good accounts to give you, mamma; the little ones have all been good this afternoon, and obeyed me in every thing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Your report delights me, Clara; but my dear, how comes it to paſs, that you do not take notice of one of your beſt friends?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA,
sp.p: My dear god-mamma! only think of my heedleſſneſs! but it was owing to the deſire I had of giving mamma pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Such a laudable motive requires commendation, as well as ſecures pardon, for what was only an overſight. God bleſs you, my beloved girl, and may you ever deſerve my affection by ſuch dutiful attention to the wiſhes of your worthy mother!

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Where is your ſiſter? I ordered John to inform her that we waited tea.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: He did. But ſhe has locked herſelf into her room, and would not admit me, but deſired me to ſay, ſhe was coming preſently.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: I muſt begin now to new model her; but muſt firſt endeavour to convince her, that I ought to regulate all her actions.—Make the tea, my dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: I hear, Miſs Clara, you are going to a ba • l, and that your papa has been ſo good as to give you new clothes to appear in.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: He has, madam, and they are all come home this afternoon, but I have not yet had time to examine them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: What would you do, if any circumſtance ſhould happen to diſappoint you of going to this ball?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Be much concerned to be ſure; but it would be for the cauſe of the diſappointment; as nothing but a miſfortune to ſome of the family could occaſion it: for papa and mamma are ſo indulgent to us, that they would not ſuffer a tri • le to prevent our enjoyment of ſuch a pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: You diſtinguiſh very juſtly, my ſweet girl: yet in all caſes of ſorrow • you muſt ſubmit with patience, becauſe it is your duty to do ſo. Misfortunes are often ſuch as no human foreſight could prevent: but the goodneſs of God enables us to overcome what unavailing tears and complaining only increaſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: My life has hitherto been a very happy one; but I am not from thence to infer, that it will always continue ſo. I can, thanks to dear mamma's care, do a great many things towards gaining a livelihood, if papa ſhould loſe his fortune.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: I am delighted to hear it. Pray inform me what your genius is moſt inclined to?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA [bluſhes.]
sp.p: O, madam, I did not mean to appear conceited; but you know mamma has taught me to draw and paint, and do all kinds of fancy work.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: And how will you make that uſeful, ſuppoſing the worſt ſhould happen?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: In every way I can. I will paint and work fanmounts and ſcreens, embroider gentlemen's waiſtcoats, and workbags and muffs for the ladies—I can alſo make work-baſkets, and Pool-diſhes; and when mamma requires it, I can aſſiſt in mending my little brothers and ſiſters cloaths.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: I am glad to hear, my dear, that you have profited ſo much by your mamma's example; and do not doubt, every proper exertion of it, ſhould circumſtances make it neceſſary, which I ſincerely hope will not be the caſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I do not think I ſhould make myſelf very miſerable if we were reduced; that is, if we had enough left to live altogether; it would only be the difference of a large and, a ſmall houſe; of a few, inſtead of a great many ſervants. I would wait upon my mamma, and ſupply her maid's place, for I can dreſs hair very tolerably.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: You can do very well for one ſo young; but could you ſubmit to being placed at a trade for life?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA [ſtartled.]
sp.p: I ſhould not like to be ſeparated from my mamma. Tho if Mrs. Gates would take me, I think, nay, I am certain, I could ſubmit to gain my bread as a mantua-maker.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Go, my love, and tell Matilda I am offended at her not coming when I ſend for her.

Her innocent converſation diſtreſſes, whilſt it delights me. Bleſſed with ſuch a daughter, I ought not to repine at any misfortune, which is not brought on by my own imprudence or impropriety of conduct.

div.stage: [Enter Miſs FREEMAN dreſſed in all her new cloaths, with a profuſion of feathers, flowers, &c. on her head, followed by her ſiſter.]

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: There mamma, look how charmingly my dreſs is made; and ſee what an elegant cap Madam Buffon has ſent me. O what taſte the French milliners have!

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Matilda, to ſee you ſo fond of dreſs, and could I have ſuppoſed you capable of trifling over new cloaths a whole afternoon, I would never have conſented to your having them. I bluſh that you ſhould be capable of expoſing yourſelf, not only to me, but before Mrs. Allworthy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: I ſee Matilda's faults with great concern Miſs; yet I think ſhe will be perſuaded to overcome them.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I never heard, madam, that there was any fault in trying on new cloaths; and always ſuppoſed an elegant taſte in dreſs was a very commendable qualification.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p:
But there is a wide difference, my dear girl, betwixt making it the buſineſs of our lives, and attending to it ſufficiently to make us
〈◊〉 and like gentlewomen. Beſides, there is nothing requires more attention to propriety of time and place than dreſs. View yourſelf, and conſider whether you make an appearance that would be to your advantage, ſuppoſing any acquaintance ſhould accidentally come into tea.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I could eaſily explain the cauſe of it; and I think every perſon muſt admire my dreſs, for it is the moſt charming one I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Certain as you ſeem to be, Miſs Matilda, of univerſal admiration, I cannot help thinking, that with your preſent appearance you would be diſappointed. Your gown, though elegant, loſes its effect, by the miſerable ſtate of your hair, which gives me the idea of porcupine quills, intermixed with feathers; and the ornaments tho' exqui • te in their kind, inſtead of adorning, only give you a ridiculous look.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: I think we have ſaid enough to convince Matilda that ſhe had better retire, and lay by her cloaths for a proper ſeaſon.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I never intended to keep them on long, but thought you would like to ſee me, as I had dreſſed myſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: If that was really your motive, my dear, I will gratify your wiſhes, by telling you that I think your dreſs very pretty, and do not doubt, when it is put on with propriety, and for a-ball, it will appear very elegant; and now let me adviſe you to take it off, leſt you ſhould meet with ſome accident.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I will go directly, madam, I would not ſpoil it for the world. [She walks off looking behind her, admiring her train—with the corner of her hoop ſhe ſweeps down a cup and ſaucer, and ſpills the tea all over her: Miſs Clara jumps up to aſſiſt her.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: O ſiſter, what a ſad accident!

sp.speaker: Miſſ FREEMAN [burſts into tears.]
sp.p: Sad indeed! what ſhall I do? Papa will never give me another dreſs, and I ſhall not be able to go to the ball. What an unfortunate creature I am!

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p:
You are like a great many other people, my dear, commit an error, and then call yourſelf unfortunate; your
accident was entirely occaſioned by your pre • ering your own opinion to the judgment of others. [Rings the bell.] Let Williams go with you to take off your things; perhaps with her care, they may eſcape better than you imagine.

div.stage: [Enter Williams.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Miſs Freeman has had an accident with her dreſs, you muſt endeavour, Williams, to recover it as well as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I am very ſorry poor Matilda has met with ſuch a misfortune. She ſhall be welcome to my dreſs if it will fit her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: My mind is too much engroſſed by more material thoughts, to dwell on this circumſtance; but I think, with care, her dreſs will not be much the worſe; and if it ſhould, it may ſerve as a leſſon in future, againſt falſe pride and vanity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Poor Matilda; one brought up as ſhe has been, could not meet a greater diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Amidſt all her errors, I do not believe ſhe is really illnatured; different as the life ſhe leads with us is from that ſhe led at her aunt's, ſhe appears to me to ſubmit to it cheerfully; and though ſhe does not follow any of the advice that I give her, ſtill ſhe liſtens without murmuring.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: From whence you may indulge the pleaſing hope of ſoon moulding her to your wiſhes.

div.stage: [Enter Miſs Freeman.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Well, my love, how fares your dreſs?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Better than I could have expected, and Williams flatters me, that by to-morrow it will be little the worſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I am glad of that; for indeed, ſiſter, I felt great concern for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Tell me honeſtly, Matilda, do not you wiſh you had employed yourſelf uſefully this afternoon, inſtead of throwing your time away in ſo trifling a manner?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: To be ſure I do, becauſe then I ſhould not have hurt my dreſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: But does it not teach you the neceſſity of never being idle? had you aſſiſted Clara in attending to the young one's, you would not have had any time to miſ • mploy.

sp.speaker: Miſſ FREEMAN.
sp.p: If I could acquire a reliſh for employment it would be a comfort to me. What can I do mamma?

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: Take pleaſure in reading, writing, working, and if you have taſte, apply to the ſeveral accompliſhments, ſo admirable in moſt of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I ſhould never have time to do ſo much, nor is there I think a neceſſity for it, at leaſt for working, becauſe the ſervants can be employed about that; and as for writing, what uſe is that of?

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: In my opinion, nothing marks a gentlewoman more than excelling in both; writing, is indeed, particularly neceſſary, as even from a note you may judge of the education of the perſon who executed it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p:
True; and it is a qualification that excites a great deal of praiſ • , which ought to be an inducement for acquiring it. Indeed, I would rather a child of mine could work and write well, than excel in what are peculiarly termed accompliſhments; though even the • atter are ſo eſſential
to a polite education, that I ſhould be ſorry to ſee the •• wanting.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: If I could only write and work, what could I do to aſſiſt mamma, in caſe of her being reduced to poverty?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: If you had not been better inſtructed, more could not be expected from you, but we may hope to reap great benefit, where great pains have been beſtowed.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I have had more maſters than my ſiſter without knowing half ſo much.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: You have been unfortunate my dear, and bred up by an aunt who indulged you without conſidering the injury ſhe did to your future proſpects; with your good ſenſe, I think, all that may be eaſily overcome.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Every thing appears new to me, and I am quite bewildered. Mamma ſeems perfectly good and kind to me, and ſtill I feel under a reſtraint before her which I never experienced with my aunt; what can be the meaning of it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p:
Believe me, dear girl, I am anxioſly ſolicitous for your welfare, and for that reaſon, lament your being educated by your aunt. I need not ſay, that her ſentiments did not accord with mine. The difference of our birth, made the difference of opinion. Life flowed ſmoothly with her, ſhe had no trials, and poſſeſſed an income that inſured her reſpect and adulation. I have experienced a very contrary fortune, and was early initiated in ſcenes of ſorrow. My father being an officer, felt diſtreſs himſelf, and pitied it in many who belonged to our regiment. No tongue can deſcribe the ſcenes of woe I have witneſſed; the more melancholy, becauſe the objects were good and brave. By theſe, my heart has been ſoftened, and though by my marriage, I have been in very affluant circumſtances
I could never forget the poverty of my former companions.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I ſhall be aſhamed to expoſe my ignorance, or I would begin taking pains about ſomething; but the worſt is, I am equally unknowing in every thing, and therefore have no hopes of ever regaining loſt time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Fear not, Miſs Matilda, a good reſolution and endeavours will aſſiſt you beyond imagination.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: It grows late; I wonder we neither ſee or hear from Mr. Freeman!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Do not let that trouble you, my dear friend, ſuſpend your apprehenſions.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: My dependence and reliance are placed where conſolation never fails, and I doubt not a mitigation to my anxiety in proper time.

div.stage: [Enter a Footman with a letter which he gives to his miſtreſs and goes out.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: From my huſband!
sp.stage: [She reads it with agitation, her daughters watch her countenance attentively.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: All is loſt!

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN and Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: What is loſt? Dear mamma, do not keep us in ſuſpence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Reſtrain your emotions a little while, my dears, this ſhall be ſoon explained; at preſent, your mamma is too much agitated to be able to talk to you.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I hope no accident has happened to papa, dear mamma, [ſhe throws her arms around Mrs. Freeman's neck.] Lean upon my ſhoulder and tell me what afflicts you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN [compoſes herſelf.]
sp.p: I am much recovered; though ſadly hurt, that my dear children muſt partake this affliction with me. Your father's loſſes in trade are very great. In ſhort, he has not more than enough left to ſatisfy his creditors. [She preſſes each daughter to her heart.] Let us determine to ſubmit to our fate with becoming fortitude, and mutually unite in endeavouring to ſupport poor Mr. Freeman, who requires every conſolation.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN,
sp.p: What will become of me? what 〈◊〉 I do? we are as badly off as Mrs. Gates; and if any body ſhould ſlight me, it will break my heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: You are very ſelfiſh in your grief Matilda, and think only for yourſelf. Look there, [pointing to her mamma.] direct your attention to that object, forget your ſorrows, and relieve her's.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I do not know what to ſay to her. I cannot help crying; it is cruel to expect ſo much from me.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Compoſe yourſelf, deareſt mamma, for all our ſakes. I will do every thing I can to be uſeful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: I do not doubt it, and am quite reſigned to our fate. May you, my dear Clara, practice, what in theory appeared ſo eaſy to you, for now it is become neceſſary, and may your ſiſter benefit by your example. I muſt go to my young ones, ſoon will they be without another attendant.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA, [ſobbing.]
sp.p: Do not ſay ſo, I will be their nurſe, and ſave you all the trouble in my power.

sp.speaker: Mrs. FREEMAN.
sp.p: I neither fear your intentions or doubt your abilities, and will put them to a trial. Stay with your ſiſter, and endeavour to reaſon her into reſignation. Mrs. Allworthy, you will accompany me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Moſt willingly.
sp.stage:
[They go out. Miſs CLARA runs and throws her arms round her ſiſter's neck, and they continue crying ſome time,
〈◊〉
then recollects herſelf.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: How ill am I performing my mamma's injunctions! ſhe bid me conſole you • and I am, by my own grief, adding to your's.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: What miſerable wretches are we all become! now muſt I ſubmit, perhaps, to be a ſervant; or, what is worſe, work for a daily ſubſiſtence.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: If I am not obliged to be an apprentice, I ſhall think myſelf happy. To be ſeparated from mamma, will indeed be a ſad ſtroke.

sp.speaker: Miſſ FREEMAN.
sp.p: Only think how Miſſ Foley will rejoice in my down fall. I muſt ſit below her and every body elſe. [cries again with violence.]

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I ſhould never ſuffer ſuch thoughts as theſe to diſtreſs me. Now we may diſcover our real friends.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: You are quite a philoſopher, Clara! I am not; but ſtill I could wiſh to be uſeful to mamma, and merit her kind approbation.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Dear Matilda, how I love you for that deſire? we ſhall never be greatly unhappy, if you will but unite your endeavours with mine to leſſen mamma's afflictions.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I wonder whether I could draw or paint fit to be ſeen I have a great inclination to try.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Do, I have not one fear of your ſucceſs; any inſtruction in my power to give, you may command.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Thank you, Clara; I may perhaps trouble you, though I will not if poſſible to avoid it. It is a ſhame for the elder to ſtand in need of being taught by the younger.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Let us forget that diſtinction, dear girl! the difference of our ages is ſmall, and I have never been ſeparated from mamma's inſtruction and example.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I begin to honor and love my dear mother, as much as you do. Her mildneſs has convinced my reaſon; had ſhe exerted any violence, I am certain ſhe would have found me obſtinate, though I muſt confeſs greatly againſt my own intereſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Parents may ſometimes be wrong, yet I never could bear to hear them found fault with by their children, and always avoided the company of thoſe who fell into that error.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: You are right, I am convinced; that thought never ſtruck me before, but I did not give myſelf time to conſider much about any thing; however, I ſhall become a new being. But do you think, Clara, mamma will ever love me as well as ſhe does you?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I have no room to believe ſhe makes any difference among any of us, in reſpect to her affection, though I muſt ſuppoſe your being guided by her better judgment, will procure you a larger portion of her eſteem than you at preſent poſſeſs.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I have a great inclination to offer her my aſſiſtance in undreſſing the young ones; perhaps it might pleaſe and conſole her, as ſhe will not like the ſervants ſhould ſee her affliction.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Very probably. Let us then unite our efforts. I ſhall tell mamma the offer was your own thought.

sp.speaker: Miss FREEMAN.
sp.p: No, I beg you will not, there is no merit in it, for ſurely it is my duty to ſave her trouble.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: But it is certainly commendable to do our duty, beſides, it will be the ſubject of great joy to mamma, that you already profit by her advice.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Come then, let us begin the ſweet labours of duty and love. I think I feel more affection for the little dears than ever I did.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Attending them is an endearing employment, and I think a very neceſſary one; for it teaches us to know our obligations to our mother, by obſerving the trouble ſhe once had with us.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I am inſpired with ſpirit and reſolution, and, perhaps, by to-morrow morning, may ſurpriſe you with my capabilities.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I ſhall be prepared for ſomething great, and rejoice at your exertions; but we ſeem to prate and forget our good intentions.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Come then. No time ſhould be loſt when a good action is in view.

div.head: SCENE, A Parlour. The breakfaſt things.
div.stage: [A Servant ſhews in Mrs. Allworthy, then goes out.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: I HOPE to find this diſtreſſed family more compoſed; and that a good night's reſt has calmed their ſpirits. Poor creatures, what a ſtruggle appeared in their exertions laſt night to ſupport each other. Their virtuous reſolution deſerves, and will, I doubt not, be rewarded. How much more does ſuch a conduct excite our pity and admiration, than weak unavailing complaints and deſpondency, which render people unfit to aſſiſt themſelves, or to be aſſiſted by others.
sp.stage: [Miſs Clara peeps into the room, then enters.]

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Allworthy, I wiſhed to find you alone, and am happily come in time to meet you ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: What has my dear girl to ſay? I ſhould ſuppoſe ſomething of great conſequence by that anxious countenance.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I have indeed ſomething of the firſt conſequence to mention, which has kept me from ſleeping all night. It is about my new cloaths; you know I can never wear them now, and it will be a ſad pity for papa to pay for them when he is in ſuch diſtreſs, and beſides they will be uſeleſs. I wiſh my dear ſecond mother, you would endeavour to diſpoſe of them among the numerous young ladies with whom you are acquainted.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: It is time enough to think upon that ſubject, my dear, you had better not be haſty.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: My mind is ſo bent upon removing this load from them, that I can think of nothing elſe; do, deareſt mamma, promiſe to aſſiſt me on this occaſion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Depend on it, my love, every thing in my power you may command.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I knew you would not diſappoint my wiſhes. But I have now another favor to obtain, which you muſt grant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: You know me well enough, Clara, to be certain, that I can deny you no reaſonable requeſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Liſten to me then with patience. I think it my duty to aſſiſt my papa and mamma as far as my power goes—will not you agree with me in that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Certainly. But to what does all this tend?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: To a very good point, as you ſhall hear. My cap. there is no doubt of the milliner's readily taking again, and ſo I diſpoſe of my ornaments, which are the laſt I ſhall ever have. But my harpſichord and muſic will ſurely afford a ſmall ſum of money, which would in an emergency be very acceptable; the motive of my ſelling them, without the knowledge of my parents, is for fear their tenderneſs for me ſhould oppoſe it. What uſe can muſic be of to me, who muſt work for my bread? It would be ridiculous you know, Mrs. Allworthy, in ſuch a ſituation, to diſplay any faſhionable accompliſhments.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p:
I am delighted with the dutiful attention you pay to the preſent unhappineſs of your worthy father and mother, whoſe diſtreſs would be more ſupportable but for
the conſideration of their children. I eſteem you for thinking ſo deeply, and hope the ſame ſolicitude will influence every future action of your life, which relates to them; but I cannot agree with you, that it is right to take any ſteps, though for the relief of your parents, without their knowledge and concurrence.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Believe me, madam, I would not, on any common occaſion, preſume to act without their conſent; but this is ſo peculiar a circumſtance. It is ſelling what can no longer be of uſe, and is, beſides, my own, for my uncle gave me the inſtrument when I was a very little girl.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Still, my dear girl, I muſt ſupport my own opinion. Indeed, you are in an error to indulge ſuch a wiſh, though to benefit your neareſt and deareſt relations.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I never was diſpoſed to rebel before; but now, if I was older, ſhould like to oppoſe my opinion to your's, and abide by my own.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: At any age, I fear ſuch conduct would draw its own puniſhment upon you. Why ſhould I oppoſe your intentions, but from motives of kindneſs?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I know it, deareſt madam, and yet to give up a plan I have been all night bringing, as I thought, to perfection, and all to procure unexpected relief to my beloved parents▪

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p:
The thought, the deſign, is worthy of a feeling generous heart, with ſuch endearing ſentiments as theſe you will beſtow peace on many, and enſure it for yourſelf. But let me entreat you never to indulge the wiſh of doing any thing in ſecret. Think with what perſpicuity your amiable mother judges. As ſoon as your papa's affairs are arranged, ſhe will inſtantly ſettle the proper regulations for all her family, and diſpoſe of what will not be for your benefit to preſerve. Let us however, my love,
[takes her hand,] drop this ſubject for the preſent. You will coincide with my opinion by and by, and thank me for being, what now appears peremptory—tell me how your mamma does, and whether ſhe obtained any reſt laſt night?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I have great pleaſure in telling you ſhe is wonderfully well and compoſed, but deſired to have her breakfaſt ſent up, as ſhe is buſy in regulating ſome bills and books which ſhe cannot leave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: It is time then to send her ſome refreſhment; come, my dear, make the tea, I am rather in want of ſome myſelf, as I have been up theſe four hours.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I beg your pardon very ſincerely, but my mind has been ſo entirely engroſſed with my ſchemes, I never thought of eating. [She ſeats herſelf at the table, but looks diſpirited and diſappointed.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Is your ſiſter with her mamma?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: No, madam, ſhe got up very early, and ſhut herſelf into our dreſſing room; whatever her employment is, it muſt be of great conſequence, for ſhe has been there, undiſturbed, ever ſince ſix o'clock. We will ſend • or her. [As ſhe gets up to ring the bell.

div.stage: [Enter Miſs Freeman, with a drawing for a fan-mount in her hand.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Good morning to you, my dear, what ſtudy has kept you ſo long alone?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p:
I hope one, that will in time prove of ſome conſequence to me. See the firſt fruits of my labour! [laying the drawing on the table.] I would not break my faſt till I finiſhed the taſk I ſet myſelf, of endeavouring to copy the fan-mount Clara ſhewed me yeſterday. I muſt beg
her to inſtruct me how to paint it. I think, with pains, I may do better than I apprehended I ſhould be able to do.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: How well you have imitated my outlines. O! ſiſter, what an acquiſition has inclination and application already gained you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Dear girl! how this early inſtance of real attention, both to yourſelf and friends, endears you to me; continue but your endeavours, and ſucceſs will attend you. At ſight of this, your parents will loſe the recollection of their laſs in your gain, of ſuch moment to your future well doing.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I am very ſolicitous to obtain my mamma's love, for it is irkſome to live unregarded by any one.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: That was not your caſe ſurely Matilda; my dear mother might ſometimes appear ſerious, but I believe ſhe really regarded you as affectionately as ſhe could.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: My conſciouſneſs of not deſerving it may make me ſuſpicious. However, I think, if I can but model myſelf to my papa's wiſhes and her's, I ſhall be as much beloved as any one.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I will carry up mamma's tea, and wait on her myſelf, it may be pleaſanter than ſending a ſervant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: How much the change I already perceive is wrought in your diſpoſition delights me! may you, my beloved girl, continue to feel the real advantage of employment, and make uſe of your time, which, once loſt, can never be regained.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I hope my mind will be as ſteady as my preſent intentions are ardent; I ſhall endeavour to be good, and I cannot do more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: True; but you have not yet proved the efficacy of endeavours, they will eſtabiſh good habits in time; which once acquired, will, I hope, remain permanent, for life.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I have been all night thinking what is to become of me, and making reſolutions. Yet ſurely, I am very much to be pitted, who have been bred up with the expectation of a great fortune, and now when I could enjoy it am diſappointed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Every ſpecies of diſtreſs is the ſubject of commiſſeration to the humane. Yet how many hundreds now ſink under afflictions heavier than yours, without one alleviating circumſtance, but what ariſes from a dependence on Providence?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I do not think any diſtreſs can exceed mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: And why your's in particular?—you certainly ſhare diſtreſs with your family, but your misfortune is not greater than theirs.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Surely, madam, my aunt's bringing me up to the expectation of a great fortune, without hinting at the poſſibility of a reverſe, adds much to my preſent diſappointment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: True, my dear, you have laboured under many diſadvantages. Falſe pride, which has been the bane of many, was early inſtilled into your young mind, and will require reaſon and religion to overcome it. The cure is already begun, by your opening your ears to the admonitions of your friends, by which you diſcern how wrong it will be, to retain opinions calculated only to miſguide you.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I ſincerely wiſh to be as amiable as my ſiſter, did I but know how to become ſo!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: By copying all that is praiſeworthy in her. Let us now go and pay our reſpects to your mamma.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I will attend you with pleaſure, madam.

div.head: SCENE, changes to another Parlour.
div.stage: [Enter the two Miſs Foley's.]

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: How I will mortify that proud inſolent girl, and make her feel that I am now her ſuperior.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT.
sp.p: You could not ſurely come hither with ſo cruel a • eſign? I would not have accompanied you had I ſuſpected it.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: And therefore I kept my thoughts to myſelf. What, do you think I will not re • ort on the proud minx when I have the opportunity?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT.
sp.p: I hear them on the ſtairs, and dread the meeting.

div.stage: [Enter the Miſs Freemans.]

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.stage: [juſt riſes from her chair, and ſinks into it immediately.]
sp.p: Your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT.
sp.p: How do you do, ladies? I hope we ſee you well?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Very well, I thank you, pray ſit down.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what is the matter with Miſs Freeman? why, you are as mute as a fiſh:

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: My ſiſter is the ſame as uſual, I believe, but we cannot command our ſpirits at all times.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: And cannot ſhe anſwer for herſelf? There was a time when Matilda did not need the aid of her meek ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I am obliged to Clara for ſpeaking, and think it hard you ſhould reprove her for it.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: O! by no mean. I reprove her, for what? ſhe is very welcome to ſpeak. I can think of nothing but the ball to-night, and the dreſs I ſhall appear in. We ſhall meet you of courſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY
sp.p: What can make you cry, Miſs Freeman? you who are to eclipſe all the young ladies by your ſuperior finery?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: We ſhall not on this occaſion outv • e any one, for we are not to be there.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT.
sp.p: I am extremely concerned for that.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: Not there? you muſt miſtake! child, for I know you have new dreſſes for the purpoſe. Send them however, that ſomething belonging to you may be taker notice of.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I ſee, Miſs Foley you are cruel enough to rejoice in our diſtreſs, therefore I will complete your triumph, by informing you, that in all probability, we ſhall never go to any balls as long as we live.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: Pray, then, what are you to go to?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA, [greatly agitat • d.]
sp.p: To ſervice, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: To ſervice • then you muſt change your names. I ſhould 〈◊〉 upon that, if you offered yourſelves to me.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT. [with great concern.]
sp.p: Dear girls, how my heart bleeds for you, I had heard ſomething of your papa's loſſes, but hoped to find it only report.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: It is too true; but we are all reſigned to our fate; indeed, with ſuch an example 〈◊〉 mamma's before us, it would be ſhameful if we were not.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT.
sp.p: You have not yet my dear Clara, experienced the ſad reverſe, and I hope never will, at leaſt, not to the degree of ſervitude.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p:
What ſignifies the d • gree. They will eaſily get places. I will ſpeak to Lady Grogram. She told me
• etaved gentlewomen were the pleaſanteſt of all domeſticks; they were ſo patient, and bore reproof better than any others.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT.
sp.p: F • e! ſiſter 〈◊〉 is cruel to add to their diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: Add to it? why they ſhould be innured to what they muſt meet with; reſpect never follows the indigent.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN. [with ſome ſpirit.]
sp.p: We need not make ourſelves quite ſo deſpicable, as to live with a modern fine lady; that would be to give up all pretenſions to reſpect at once.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: You muſt give up your ſpirit, madam, or you will ſoon be turned out of doors go where you will, and then to whom will you apply for relief?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Not to you Miſs Foley. I ſhall trouble you on no occaſion, believe me.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it; for I hate dependent acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: We ſhall, I truſt have no occaſion to ſeek to any; for we do not deſpair of being ſought by the worthy and the good.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p:
O, are theſe your hopes? Th •
〈◊〉 probably you do 〈◊〉 deſpair of being rich again and ſ ••• ing yourſelves above us?

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I bluſh to think I was ever capable of acting ſo meanly, and ſincerely aſk Miſs Harriot's pardon for my behaviour the laſt time we met. Clara convinced me yeſterday of the impropriety of my conduct towards you; and to-day my own feelings ſtrengthen and confirm her argument. [Looks ſteadfaſtly at Miſs Foley.]

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: You are very impertinent in your manner, Matilda; but people who mix with their inferiors, muſt expect to meet impertinence. Come Harriot, let us go; or do you intend to ſtay crying over theſe girls all day?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT.
sp.p: If they will permit me to aſſist in comforting them, I ſhall be obliged by it. Accept my company, dear girls, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p:
Your offer is a very kind one, my dear Miſs Harri ••
but we cannot think of interfering with the ball: to-morrow, if you will favor us, we ſhall be 〈◊〉 of your company.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: It is a vain wiſh. Mamma will never ſuffer my ſiſter to keep low company.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p:
I thank you, Miſs Foley, for opening my 〈…〉
you argue now, did I yeſterday about 〈…〉 and treated her very inſolently; how I heartily repent having done ſo. Take warning, therefore, by my 〈◊〉 and miſfortune; the latter may be your's; but it will 〈◊〉 half its bitterneſs if unaccompanied by the former.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY. [diſdainfully.]
sp.p: It is not for ſuch people as you to give advice.—Do you part with your inſtrument? what a fooliſh queſtion; that you do of courſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p:
Certainly; I ſhall never think of attending to muſic, 〈◊〉 it ſhould be neceſſary to recommend me in whatever
ſtation papa fixes on for me. Mrs. Allworthy thinks I am qualified as a teacher to a ſchool.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: A bleſſed life you will paſs; and Matilda's delicate hands to trundle a mop.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT.
sp.p: For ſhame! ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: If ſhe is ſunk below your pity, let her alſo be below your contempt.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: I am ſunk in fortune, it is true, but I muſt be abject indeed to wiſh to obtain any thing from Miſs Foley, but her abſence, or her ſilence.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: Am I ordered out of this houſe by you? impertinence! for this behaviour, I will never ſpeak one word in your favor.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: You have treated me, Miſs Foley, as I deſerve, and have done me an eſſential piece of ſervice; but tell me, could you, even by a look, indicate an unkind thought to my patient amiable mother?

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: I ſhould look at her the ſame as I do at other people, perhaps leſs embarraſſed now ſhe is beneath me; for ſome how I uſed rather to ſtand in awe of her.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: You make me angry, Miſs Foley, by ſaying, my deareſt mother is beneath you. But I recollect myſelf; ſhe would only ſmile at ſuch a remark, and I am proud to follow her example.

div.stage: [Enter Mrs. Allworthy.]

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: You look remarkably cheerful; dear madam, what occaſions it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: The ſight of your papa. He is returned home, and appears uncommonly well.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: I rejoice to hear it, may I go and ſee him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Not immediately, he has people on buſineſs with him. Your mamma is coming preſently.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: As my papa is in health and ſpirits, he will be more capable of directing us in future, and comforting mamma.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: She does not appear at preſent to want comfort, for ſhe poſſeſſes every thing ſhe can wiſh for in this world.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY.
sp.p: But fortune; and I fancy every body finds that a very neceſſary ingredient to happineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: How can Mrs. Freeman want fortune? it is well known that Mr. Freeman is one of the richeſt merchants in the city.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: O, madam! you need not conceal from Miſs Foley our miſfortunes, ſhe knows them, not only from us, but from report.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Then I muſt have the pleaſure of telling her, report is not always to be depended upon. For Mr. Freeman's ſhips are ſafely arrived in the river; and he has heard, that another, which he thought taken by the enemy, has only been detained by contrary winds, in a neutral port theſe two months, and is hourly expected.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: No wonder you looked ſo pleaſed, madam, for your goodneſs leads you to rejoice with every body that is fortunate.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT.
sp.p: I do ſincerely congratulate you on this happy event, and am rejoiced to hear it.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY. [looks very much confuſed.]
sp.p: I wiſh you joy. Who could have thought it! Come, ſiſter, we had better go.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT.
sp.p: I am ready to attend you, with a lighter heart than I brought hither.

sp.speaker: Miſs FOLEY. [confuſed.]
sp.p: I ſuppoſe theſe ladies wi •• go to the ball now. Shall we have the honor of going with you? we can call on you in our coach if agreeable.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: You are very obliging: but we cannot think of the ball, till we have ſeen papa and mamma, and known if it is agreeable to them for us to go.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: As Miſs Foley had made the offer of taking us, we can let her know as ſoon as this matter is determined for us.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARRIOT.
sp.p: Do then; we ſhall be happy to join your party. Good morning to you. [They curteſy and go out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Let me now preſs my dear girls to my heart, and congratulate them on returning proſperity.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: You ſhould alſo rejoice in my adverſity; for it has done me more good than riches poſſibly could have done. I was inclined to give up falſe pride by my mamma's arguments and yours; but Miſs Foley's conduct this morning has I hope extinguiſhed every latent ſpark of it; ſhe ſhewed me my own picture; I pity her error, though I deſpiſe in her thoſe faults which made my own character contemptible.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: Indeed, ſiſter, you have ſhewn more forbearance than I could have practiſed. Miſs Foley has been more unfee • ingly inſolent than I thought any perſon capable of being.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: You forget my conduct yeſterday to poor Mrs. Gates; it 〈…〉 as inexcuſable.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: But, Matilda, how could you promiſe to go to the ball with them, in caſe we ſhould be permitted to go? you cannot think of it.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Why not? it is my intentions to accept her invitation to night, and at all proper times; not only to ſhew to her that I am above reſenting her treatment, but alſo, that the ſight of her may remind me of my own faults, and with a ſecret hope, that the change in my conduct, may effect an alteration in her's.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: You judge nobly my dear girl. Continue to think thus, and falſe pride, the bane of peace, will not endanger the loſs of your future repoſe. Well, Clara, will you liſten to my admonitions in future? was not my advice better to follow than your own.

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: O dear, madam, I bluſh at the recollection of my earneſtneſs, and beg your pardon for it.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: What did you do then, Clara? I long to know.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: We will talk of it another time; though it is nothing but what muſt redound to her credit, and prove her duty and attention to her parents.

div.stage: [Enter Maid.]

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: My lady ſent me to beg one of the young ladies would come to the hair dreſſer, who has been waiting ſome time.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN.
sp.p: Then we are to go to the ball; will you go firſt, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Miſs CLARA.
sp.p: If it is moſt agreeable to you?

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: My miſtreſs had been enquiring about a box of fine things belonging to you Miſs, and is afraid ſomebody has ſtolen it.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN. [bluſhes, in confuſion.]
sp.p: I have it; run and tell mamma. [in confuſion Maid goes out.] I am ſorry now I took them; but it was to get you to ſell them; and carry the money to her. I had nothing elſ:e to give; could I then refuſe to part with what was of no uſe to me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: But it was wrong to take them clandeſtinely, and might have been productive of great uneaſineſs to your mamma. I muſt read both your ſiſter and you a lecture on this ſubject; for her offence was of a ſimilar nature.

sp.speaker: [Enter MAID.]
sp.p: My maſter is gone into miſtreſs is dreſſing room, and deſires to ſee you there, ladies.

sp.speaker: Miſs FREEMAN. [cries.]
sp.p: What can be the matter with me; I was never happier in my life, and yet I cannot reſtrain my tears.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: Senſibility frequently produces this effect, that is now your caſe. But go, my love, to your papa, and receive in his careſſes the reward you merit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ALLWORTHY.
sp.p: The goodneſs of Providence has removed the affliction of this worthy family, and conviction has 〈…〉 arrogant pride; her behaviour to Miſs 〈…〉 I overheard by being in the next room) 〈…〉 about her reformation alſo, and 〈…〉 REASON. I will now join th • s 〈…〉 in decorating the dear 〈◊〉 for the 〈◊〉 .

div.p: THE CONTRAST, A DRAMA, IN THREE ACTS,

div.head: THE CONTRAST A DRAMA, IN THREE ACTS.
SCENE. I.
div.stage: [Mrs. Vernon at breakfaſt, attended by her Maid.]
[Enter Miſs Selwyn, who advances to the table and takes her grandmamma's hand.]

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: GOOD morning to you, my dear grandmamma, I hope you reſted well laſt night, and feel no remains of the rheumatic pains you complained of?

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Thank you, my dear girl, I am as well as I can expect to he at my late 〈◊〉 of life, though I have ſtill the ſame pains flying about me.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN, [who ſits down.]
sp.p:
I am extremely 〈◊〉 for it. Is your breakfaſt as you like it? your 〈◊〉 does not look ſo nice as uſual; you do not 〈◊〉 to 〈◊〉 it.
〈◊〉
you had better, if you pleaſe, make another.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p:
Your 〈◊〉 is very grateful to my feelings; but indeed my maid has done every thing as uſual. It is not wonderful that appetite of an old woman near eighty
ſhould f •• l her, who is too infirm to take the benefit of freſh air and exerciſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: What would I give that I could by any means remove ſome of your infirmities? then my dear grandmamma might enjoy herſelf abroad as I do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Undoubtedly. Health is certainly one of the greateſt bleſſings we can poſſeſs; but unfortunately, we ſeldom know how to price it, till loſt by our own miſmanagement. The youthful too generally imagine they ſhall never be old; and therefore throw away the moſt precious part of their lives in folly and diſſipation, which occaſions conſtant regret for miſpent time, and embitters all their latter years. My comfort is, that I feel only the natural infirmities of age; my conſcience does not reproach me on this head.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Young people who have a grandmamma and mamma like mine, can ſurely never be ſubject to ſuch errors.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: We are to hope they have not ſuch advantages as you have, my dear. Sally, take away, and give me my knotting bag.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: You are never idle, madam. With your permiſſion, I will fetch my embroidery, and keep you company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Do ſo, my love. [Miſs Selwyn goes out.] Rub this table a little more, Sally.

sp.speaker: SALLY.
sp.p: How very pretty Miſs grows, Madam!—ſhe will be a perfect beauty in time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: She has a good heart, and a ſweet diſpoſition: thoſe are durable perfections. Let me hear no flattery, Sally.

div.stage: [Enter Miſs Selwyn with her frame, which ſhe places properly and begins to work.]

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I have often wondered, my dear grandmamma, to think how it is poſſible for you to be ſo cheerful who are always in pain, and neither can viſit or be much viſited.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Many circumſtances conduce to my cheerfulneſs. My Creator, as one of his bountiful gifts, has endowed me with an active mind, in conſequence of which, I have acquired a habit of conſtant employment. But above all, the reliance which a long life has taught me to place on my Maker, naturally produces ſerenity of mind; and I look back with ſatisfaction on the days that are paſt, as I truſt, guided by his unerring hand, I have not ſpent them unprofitably. I am ſure I have not unthankfully. The bleſſings I enjoy are manifold. Miſfortunes I have ſhared with the reſt of mankind. Grateful and reſigned, I wait for the moment of my diſſolution.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I hope, however, that your life will be ſpared many years longer; for I have a great deal to learn; and though my mamma is all goodneſs, yet ſhe has not ſo much time for converſation as you have; beſides, it would break my heart to be ſeparated from you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON, [ſmiling.]
sp.p: The heart, my dear, is not ſo ea ••• y broken as you imagine; great and heavy have been my afflictions. My mind was naturally weak, and apt to repine at every diſappointment, this my parents early obſerved, their kind attention to me ſtrengthened it; they ſoon convinced me, that a dependance on this world is vain, and taught me to draw confolation from that ſource which never fails. At what time may we expect the travellers? are you not impatient to ſee your couſin?
