sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p:
Indeed I am. Mamma told me at parting that ſhe hoped to be at home by dinner to-day, and I ordered it accordingly. I am afraid my appearance will be very aukward in the company of
〈◊〉 . Seven years reſidence
in France, has no doubt, made her all accompliſhed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: I hope it has improved her, or it will be ſeven years thrown away: but why ſhould you be aukward, becauſe ſhe is accompliſhed? you have had the advantage of a good education, and under the eye of an amiable mother, whoſe acquirements and conſtant attention muſt have given you a benefit your couſin wanted, ſeparated as ſhe has been for ſuch a length of time from all her relations.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: My aunt holds me ſo cheap for having been educated in England, though the forbears to ſpeak her ſentiments, I think her looks ſeem to ſay, when my mamma kindly commends my behaviour, "my daughter will ſoon convince you whoſe judgment is the beſt."

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: You ſhould avoid all ſuſpicions of this kind: for it is ungenerous to judge of 〈◊〉 paſſes in the minds of others merely for their looks; had your mamma thought as you do, I dare ſay ſhe would have been equally hurt, but would have forborn to expreſs her chagrin to any one.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I ſaw yeſterday morning tears ſtart into her eyes, at a remark my aunt made on home education, but it is true, that inſtead of taking it up, ſhe only turned and embraced me with the greateſt affection, and ſeemed, whilſt ſhe preſſed me to her boſom, to ſay, "I am ſatiſfied with you." My aunt was too full of her approaching meeting with Cecilia, to ſay even adieu to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p:
The neglect was pardonable. I muſt not have you think of it. Your mamma's conduct through life will be an excellent guide for you. Be thankful to GOD that you have before your eyes ſuch an example. She has ſacrificed her own feelings on many occaſions; and when I loſt my ſon, conſented, for my ſake, to take your aunt and couſins into this houſe. You are old enough to remark, that they are in ſome reſpects different from 〈◊〉
both in ſentiment and character: yet to this ſhe has ſubmitted, and without once deviating from the reſpect which ſhe thinks due to the relief of ſo near a relation.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I am ſure, my couſin George often treats my mamma ſhamefully, and yet my aunt ſeldom reproves him for it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: It is with great concern I ſee his mother's blind indulgence towards him; but as he has a good underſtanding, I hope he will in time learn to behave with propriety.
sp.stage: [Enter Maſter Vernon haſtily, he runs to Miſs Selwyn, then ſpeaks.]
sp.p: I have broke my kite, couſin; do give me ſome paper to mend it with?

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I will give you ſome paper, George, with as much pleaſure, as ſeeing you pay duty and reſpect to your grandmamma would give me.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I do not mean to be rude to grandmamma, and will kiſs her if the pleaſes; for, indeed, ſhe is never croſs to me; but I heard Miſs Ward complain the other day, how ill-natured her grandmother was: and ſhe ſaid, ſhe did not know what uſe old women were of, if they muſt live, but to ſit in the chimney corner and knit ſtockings.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: If you have adopted this ſentiment, George, my affection can be of little eſtimation in your opinion; yet I feel myſelf your parent, and am truly anxious for your welfare.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I think Miſs Ward was quite inexcuſeable to uſe ſuch expreſſions; for if ſhe has no ſenſe of duty, or propriety herſelf, ſhe ſhould not have endeavoured to pervert the minds of others.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Very true, my love; but young people who are in habits of inſolence, ſeldom conſider to whom they addreſs it, or think of the prevalence of example.
sp.stage: [Miſs Selwyn furniſhes the young gentleman with paper, then ſpeaks.]

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: There, couſin, you may now repair the damage your kite has received; and I hope you will allow, that if old woman are uſeleſs, young one's are not ſo?

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Why, I hope you do not call yourſelf a woman? however I thank you for your kindneſs. As ſoon as I have mended my kite-and dried, it, I will go and try if it will fly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: I think I heard a carriage ſtop: if ſo, our hopes or fears, will ſoon become certainty.

div.stage: [Enter Mrs. Selwyn.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: How is my dear mother? I have had ten thouſand alarms for your health during my abſence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Your daughter has paid ſuch attention to me, that I have hardly felt your loſs: which will, I hope, induce you not to confine yourſelf ſo much as formerly. Have you brought home your ſiſter and the young Frenchwoman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: I have, madam: they only wait your permiſſion to be admitted.—My beloved Tereſa, you are dearer to me than ever, for ſhewing ſuch ſweet attention to your grandmother.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I am happy to obtain your approbation ſo easily, mamma; for in ſo doing, I have only followed the bent of my own inclinations.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Poſtpone at preſent theſe joyful effuſions.—It will be proper for Tereſa to welcome her aunt and Couſin; in the mean time. I will, with your aſſiſtance, daughter, prepare myſelf for the approaching interview.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: Go then, my love, into the parlour, and tell my ſiſter, her mother will attend her immediately.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: I am all anxiety and apprehenſion, whilſt I enquire whether my ſon's daughter is worthy of him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: Cecilia is certainly not ſuch a character as will pleaſe you. Her education may make a figure among the gay and thoughtleſs, but is no more ſuited to the pleaſures of a fire ſide, than ſuch pleaſures are ſuited to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: My fears were then prophetic when I warned her infatuated mother againſt ſending her to a convent. But what is to be expected when a child is removed ſo many years from the watchful eyes of anxious affection? will you aſſiſt me to make the uſual alteration in my dreſs, that I may avoid coming up ſtairs any more to-day; and then, with a palpitating heart, will I embrace this dear perverted child.

div.head: SCENE, changes to a Parlour.
[Mrs. G. Vernon and her daughter.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. Vernon.
sp.p: It is ſtrange no one comes to welcome us.

sp.speaker: Miſs Vernon.
sp.p: Not at all; I dare ſay my aunt is decorating and documenting Tereſa, that ſhe may not appear aukward before me, [with 〈◊〉 of her head,] ſhe may try, but I do not fancy ſhe will ſucceed very well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: You are much miſtaken, my dear. Your couſin is a very amiable and accompliſhed girl, nor does ſhe ever want decorating, for her dreſs is always neat, and ſuch as ſhe may be ſeen in before any one.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p:
Well, I allow ſhe may be neat, but ſhe cannot know
how to put her cloaths on as faſhionably as I do, for I have been dreſſed like a woman ever ſince I went to France.
sp.stage: [Enter Miſs SELWYN who goes to embrace her couſin with great affection.]
sp.p: Welcome to England, my dear Cecilia; I cannot expreſs the joy I feel that I once more ſee you in this houſe. Pardon me, aunt, for taking notice of my couſin, before I have paid my duty to you; but my joy at ſeeing her occaſioned it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON [embraces her.]
sp.p: You are forgiven, my love, for a very natural and pleaſing omiſſion; I am glad you retain the affection which, even in infancy, you felt for my Cecilia. [To her daughter, who ſtands gazing at Miſs Selwyn in an affected manner] you neither ſpeak or return your couſin's kind reception—recollect yourſelf, my dear.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: My couſin is ſo grown and altered, that I ſhould not have known her any where; but I am very happy to fee her again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: Your ſeparation, conſider has been long enough to make an equal change in both of you. How is my mother, Tereſa? perhaps ſhe may like to ſee me alone firſt. I will, therefore, find George, and then attend her in her own apartment. My abſence will accelerate your intimacy, I hope, for at preſent, young Ladies, you ſeem very diſtant to each other.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Indeed I do not mean to appear cool; but I have been ſo loſt in admiration of you, couſin, that it tied my tongue.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: You are very kind, my dear Cecilia; but I cannot be vain enough to believe what your politeneſs leads you to ſay.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p:
Doubt my veracity, child? "true as the needle to the pole."
But come, tell me ten thouſand things at once; I long to know how you amuſe yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I can ſooner tell you how I employ myſelf; for as to amuſements except joining your brother George, in his plays ſometimes, I have very few; I am, however, ſeldom unemployed: but now you are returned I may promiſe myſelf many pleaſures ſuitable to my time of life, which the want of a companion has for ſome time deprived me of.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: La, coz! you talk as if we were to play like children ſtill; I like nothing in the old ſtyle; beſides, I have too much vivacity to continue the ſame employment long, la, la, la, [ſings, and dances before the looking-glaſs.]

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: You have charming ſpirits, and will find me ready to join you in both ſinging and dancing, for I am very fond of them both.

sp.speaker: Miſs. VERNON.
sp.p: O, I adore them! am in extaſies at an Opera, and expire at the ſight of Veſtris.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: 'Tis a pity then you ſhould run the riſque of hearing and ſeeing them. I think it would give me much pleaſure to go to ſuch an entertainment; but as to expiring, I am ſure I would not venture to go, could I expect the pleaſure would be ſo exquiſite as to produce ſuch an effect upon me.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p:
You are all nonchalance. While I am endowed with Eſprit. Eſprit! that makes me the life of company.—but a ••
tonjours 〈◊〉
when alime. Have you no wiſh to go to that dear place I have juſt quitted?

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: If you mean France, I confeſs, my deſire is ſtrong to go thither: and I have my mamma's promiſe to take me, when my dear grandmamma no longer requires our attendance on her.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Does the old lady give as much good advice as ſhe uſed to do? poſſitively, if ſhe begins with me I ſhall adviſe her, knowing her great fondneſs for experiments, to ſend for Mouſieur Blunchard, and mount in one of his air ballooms, and then I will bribe him, never to let her come back again.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Fie! Cecilia, It is ſhocking to hear you talk ſo of any old woman, but of ſuch a grandmother, unpardonable.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: You muſt expect this, and a great deal more; for I always ſpeak what comes uppermoſt. It is a la mode de France.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: La mode de France is not a very pleaſant mode, if it inculcates a want of feeling and reſpect to our neareſt and deareſt relations. You have not enquired after your brother; yet he was a ſweet little fellow when you parted from him.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I have quite forgot what he was. But I know it would be better for me if I had no brother; for then I ſhould have a larger fortune.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: How can you talk ſo? what wiſh your brother dead!

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: It is no proof becauſe I wiſh myſelf to have a better fortune that I deſire my brother's death. Suppoſe he was your brother, would not that do as well?

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Well! I have no idea of indulging a wiſh for any thing to be different from what Providence has ordered it. I have often, to be ſure, wiſhed I had a ſiſter; but then the thought has been forgotten as ſoon as I obtained a companion.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p:
But conſider with what old faſhioned notions you have
been educated; never to think or ſpeak but by rule, whilſt Frolic has been my Mother, Whim my Siſter, and their dear attendant Nonſenſe, conſtantly hovering about me. Your maſters are fuſty old Engliſhmen, choſen by your grandmamma, becauſe they are mighty civil well behaved men. If you perform well, they are too phlegmatic to praiſe you; if ill, the
〈◊〉
never forget it. My inſtructors were Petit Maitres, dreſſed
〈◊〉 dernier gout, with a chapeau de bras. Whilſt I was playing, or dancing, they were all extaſies; charmante! adorable! tres bien! bon! encore! were repeated till I was even almoſt tired of hearing my own praiſes. Vive la hagatelle, ſhall be my motto, whilſt youth, (a Frenchman would ſay) and beauty remain.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I am ſure, my dear parents have always encouraged my livelineſs, and at times I have very great ſpirits; it is true, they wiſhed me to diſtinguiſh between real cheerfulneſs and levily. The latter of which, I own, is already ſo diſagreeable in my eyes, that I am ſorry to ſee any young lady encourage it.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: That is as much as to ſay, you do not like me. N'importe. The opinion of a girl bred in obſcurity, will never diſtreſs me. But your behaviour need not have been quite ſo Engliſh at our firſt meeting.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I am ſorry, couſin, you found any thing in my ſpeech to apply to yourſelf. You talked of the opera and Veſtris as having ſeen them; how was that poſſible in a Convent?

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p:
By the mean of a little art and good friends, my dear. I accompanied the mother of one of our boarders to Paris, perſuaded the Lady Abbeſs, though almoſt as old and grumpy as my grandmamma, that ſhe would o •• end mamma, if ſhe refuſed my accepting the invitation of ſo great a lady as Madame la Com •••• e de Reſſelle; under
this idea, ſhe conſented, and for one fortnight I enjoyed all the pleaſures of the beau monde.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p:
How could you receive pleaſure from any diverſion obtained by the meanneſs of deceit? I ſhould have hoped, my Cecilia, had had more pride than to deſcend to it, Seven years ago you would 〈◊〉
bluſhed at only being ſuppoſed capable of ſuch an action.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: You who have never gone beyond the pales of the village church-yard, nor heard precepts but from the old faſhioned months of your relations, have no idea what young people will ſubmit to when pleaſure is in view; for my part, I think there is no harm in an innocent deception; and often laugh at the figure I made when I went into the Convent, a little formal demure Miſs grandmamma's beſt girl: ſaid my prayers might and morning; preferred reading good books to the old lady, to a game of romps: and would not have told a menſonge for the world.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p:
I am ſorry to ſay any thing harſh to you, dear couſin, particularly in theſe firſt moments of our meeting; but indeed, if you continue to uſe ſuch expreſſions, I muſt only keep you company when you are reſtrained by the preſence of thoſe relations whom you hold ſo cheap. What you have juſt ſaid, muſt, however, be all mere
••• llery; when you are ſerious, I ſhall hear very different ſentiments, from you.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Though I do not thank you much for the former part of your ſpeech, yet I cannot help telling you, that my ſentiments never differ, for I diſclaim every thing like ſeriouſneſs; the age of ſixteen was never made for that: it is the prime of pleaſure, gaiety and dreſs. Apropos, I long to ſhew you the ſweet elegant becoming ornaments I have brought home, if the Barbares at the Cuſtom-houſe keep their odious hands from them.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I ſhall be much delighted with a ſight of them, as the French are generally allowed to have great taſte and elegance in dreſs.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: And when placed with judgment I ſay no more. Vou • me compren •• ?

div.stage: [Enter Maſter Vernon who runs and kiſſes his ſiſter.]

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: How impoli, George! you ſhould only touch my cheek.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I am not a Frenchman, ſiſter; nor do I deſire to be one, that is more. Why, I never ſaw any body • ut ſuch a queer figure in my life as you do, all frizzled and powdered. I like my couſin a great deal better.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: With all my heart; your good opinion would only make me diſlike myſelf. I wiſh dinner was ready, [takes out a dirty looking knife.] I long to exerciſe you, [addreſſing it] for I am very hungry.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: And do you think grandmamma will ſuffer ſuch a naſty looking knife as that to be uſed at the table ſhe ſits at? why, it would quick ſhock her.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: It is what I have uſed conſtantly theſe three years, and ſhall continue to cut with it in ſpite of all ſhe can ſay to the contrary; I am not quite vulgar enough to eat with one, as I ſuppoſe you all do.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: There you are miſtaken, Mrs. Frenchwoman; I often wiſh my aunt's eyes behind her, becauſe ſhe watches me ſo narrowly, for fear I ſhould put any thing to my mouth with my knife; but then we are not abſurd or dirty enough to uſe ſuch a naſty thing as that.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I wiſh you would hold your ridiculous tongue, and not talk of things you cannot underſtand. Go to ſchool, that is the propereſt place for you.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Hold your tongue—who ſent for you to give an opinion? I ſhall not ſubmit to you, indeed.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Pray reſtrain yourſelves, my dear couſins, I am extremely ſhocked to ſee ſuch near relations quarrelling, and particularly, ſo ſoon a • ter ſuch a long ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: What right has he to laugh at me? I will uſe my knife if I like it.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: And what right had you to call me impoli, or in plain Engliſh, Brute?

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I beg you will compoſe yourſelves. How much would your conduct diſtreſs all our parents, if they knew it?

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Tell them of it with all my heart; perhaps you will recommend yourſelf by it.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: No one but you, couſin, would have ſuppoſed me capable of deſigned ill-nature. But you do not know what I am, and have forgot what I was.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: You can praiſe yourſelf, however, that I can perceive. A fine chance for happineſs have I, to be documented by a conceited couſin, and a booriſh brother. But I will never let mamma reſt till ſhe removes me from this hateful houſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: You diſtreſs me greatly, Cecilia, by thus miſconſtruing my intentions, [takes her hand with great affection.] I am ſure proving myſelf ſincerely your friend will afford happineſs to myſelf; and I hope, this houſe, once ſo dear to you, and which you regretted leaving when your mamma ſent you abroad, will be 〈◊〉 highly eſtimated as ever.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: That is a vain hope: when I liked this dull ſituation, I did not know better; but now I muſt deteſt every thing like retirement. That one fortnight at Paris, has ſpoi •• me for any thing but living in the world.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: So far from making me impatient to ſee the world, you render me afraid of entering it. What dreadful effects, to make one hate home, and the peace and quietneſs to be found there only! you cannot always be amuſed from morning till night.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I am ſure we were ſo at Paris, and wanted ſtill more hours for amuſement; but then to be ſure, I was fadly fatigued, and did not recover it for many days after I returned to the Convent, but that was only for want of uſe.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Well, ſiſter, I wiſh you would talk of ſomething elſe beſides your outlandiſh manner of paſſing your time, it would do you more good to go and play at trap-b • li with me.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Keep your ſentiments to yourſelf, ſir; they are by no mean deſirable in my opinion. What is the old lady dreſſing herſelf all this time? ſhe does not ſhew much impatience to ſee me; but, perhaps, ſhe is beautifying, ha! ha! [Laughs.]

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I will enquire what is the matter; for my dear grandmamma's great age makes me conſtantly apprehenſive about her. [She rings the bell.]

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: You need not hurry her, Tereſa, for I find no difficulty to ſmother my impatience.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it. [Enter a footman.] Have you heard any thing of my grandmamma, John?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: She is now upon the ſtairs, miſs, I believe ſhe has been kept above by ſome complaint, becauſe her maid went for drops.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN. [agitated.]
sp.p: You alarm me greatly; but I will go and ſee her myſelf. [As ſhe is quitting the room, enter Sally.]

sp.speaker: SALLY.
sp.p: My lady is gone into the dining parlour with your mammas, ladies, and deſires your company there.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: How is my grandmamma, Sally? I hope not very ill?

sp.speaker: SALLY.
sp.p: No, miſs, only a little faint. But you are ſo ſoon frightened.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Frightened, indeed! I never heard ſuch a fuſs about an old woman in my life; it is quite abſurd.

sp.speaker: SALLY.
sp.p: O, Miſs Cecilia, I am glad you are come home, the houſe will ſeem alive now.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: That it will, if my endeavours can make it ſo.
sp.stage: [Sally is going to ſpeak, but is interrupted by

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: You need not ſtay here, Sally, we ſhall go to the dining parlour immediately. [Sally goes out.] How can you couſin encourage that impertinent girl to prate? it is a liberty ſhe never dared to take with me.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Keep your advice for thoſe who will attend to it, I ſhall never be a liſtner. Come, let us go, that I may be made a ſhow of.

div.head: SCENE, the Dining Parlour.
div.stage: [Mrs. Vernon, Mrs. G. Vernon, Miſs and Maſter Vernon, Mrs. and Miſs Selwyn, ſitting round the table after dinner, eating fruit, &c.]

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I KNEW very well, ſiſter, that you would not dare to pull out that naſty quee • knife, before grandmamma, notwithſtanding what you ſaid.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I think, ſir, I had enough of your imper •• ence before dinner; I muſt claim my mamma's protection from any more of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: It is a ſhame, George, that you ſhould quarrel with your ſiſter ſo ſoon after your meeting.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: O, you need not take her part; ſhe wants no ſecond, I aſſure you, mamma, ſhe was quite a match for my couſin and me together before dinner.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Tereſa, to hear that you have been diſputing, and wonder from whoſe example you could learn it?

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Indeed, my dear grandmamma, I have not deſerved your cenſure on this occaſion; George quite miſtakes.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p:
There is no occaſion to tell tales. Though, to ſpeak
truth, we had a fine battle of the tongues amongſt us; but that is nothing new to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: But it is very new in this houſe, and what we never approve. George, to be ſure, ſometimes thinking himſelf wiſer than any of us, prefers giving his opinion to hearing ours; however, we ſeldom ſpare him, for it is unpardonable, even in a rude unpoliſhed ſchool-boy, to behave in that manner, but in young ladies, it proves a want of delicacy and ſentiment. Fie, Tereſa! I thought you had too much gentleneſs to be guilty of ſuch an error.
sp.stage: [Miſs Selwyn appears to be quite diſtreſſed, but continues ſilent,]

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: We never paſſed a day in the convent without half a dozen quarrels amongſt the boarders; by which mean I am ſo accuſtomed to them, that I could not live in quietneſs for the world. You look quite aſhamed of it, couſin, why, I am not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: This is one of the bleſſed effects of the foreign education you have had; and your ſpeech convinces me, that you alone were to blame; poor Tereſa could not avoid being a ſpectator; but her diſtreſſed appearance plainly ſpeaks ſhe took no other part in the contention.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I imagine, my couſin is to be ſuppoſed always in the right, becauſe ſhe was bred at home under your tuition, grandmamma, and according to your precepts. But conſider the change of faſhions in the laſt ſixty years, and how different young people are now to what they were formerly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: It is with great concern I obſerve the alteration you mention; but ſixty years cannot make abſurdity appear like reaſon, or pertneſs, like underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p:
I ſuppoſe, if I was demure, ſimple, and ſilent, you would
call me modeſt, and well bred; but what uſe would it be to have accompliſhments if I did not try to ſhew them?

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Do you then think, Cecilia, impertinent unmeaning remarks are proofs of knowledge? you take the method to convince us of the contrary: ſilence might hide your deficiency; there is no being miſtaken when once you open your mouth.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: It is a little hard, that I may not ſpeak of the cuſtoms which prevail among people with whom I have paſſed almoſt half my life; but I ſuppoſe I am prevented, for fear I ſhould convince others that I know more than my liſteners.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Incorrigible girl! have you no affection? no feeling? no ſenſe of duty?

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: You do not give me any opportunity of ſhewing my ſentiments. It is hard to be received with frowns after ſo long an abſence, and all occaſioned by that young fripon my brother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: My dear madam, let us wave all further argument. George, give your ſiſter a reconciling kiſs, and we will call another ſubject.
sp.stage: [Maſter Vernon juſt touches Miſs Vernon's cheek, then ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Was that done gently enough to pleaſe you, madame Franc • is?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: H • ſh! George, I muſt not allow you to take ſuch liberties with your ſiſter, if you repeat it, I will inſtantly ſend you to 〈◊〉 . Did you, Tereſa, invite the young ladies to tea this afternoon?

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p:
I wrote notes to them, madam, as you directed, requeſting
their company to meet an old friend; they returned for anſwer that they ſhould be happy to wait on me, and would come early, according to my deſire.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: I hope, my dears, you will not diſpute before your viſitors.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I ſhall not begin firſt. But I am determined to go into the room to ſee how Cecilia behaves, and what frenchified airs ſhe puts on.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I do not think it worth while to argue with ſuch a rude boy as you are. Pray, couſin, who are the young ladies we are to ſee this afternoon?

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Miſs Ward, Miſs Franklin, and Miſs Thurot; the father of Miſs Thurot is a French refuge • ; the other two ladies, you no doubt recollect?

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Come then, let us go into the drawing-room and prepare for them.
[She runs out; Miſs Selwyn curtefies to her friends, and follows her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Come, my good Mrs. Selwyn, lead me to the couch in the little parlour, that I may take my afternoon's ſleep.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON, alone.
sp.p:
With what difficulty have I ſmothered my grief and diſappointment. Alas! Cecilia's temper is quite ſpoiled. O that I had followed her grandmother's advice, and educated her with her couſin; but headſtrong and opinionated people generally ſuffer as I do. What ſteps can I take to undo what ſeven years ſeem to have fatally completed? had but her father's life been ſpared, he would have ſaved her from perverſion, and me from the fatal inſtrument of being it. Why did I follow my own infatuated opinion? Too prophetic mother, all your apprehenſions
are verified! I muſt go to my daughter, and try to compoſe my mind, it is at preſent greatly diſturbed.

div.head: SCENE changes to the Drawing-Room.
[Miſs Selwyn, Miſs and Maſter Vernon.]

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I long to hear you play on the harpſichord, Cecilia; I ſhall hope to improve myſelf, by catching your graces.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you have an Engliſh maſter and Engliſh 〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I play of all kinds; my maſter is ſtill the ſame you began with, and is reckoned a remarkably good one.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: He may be thought ſo here, but I was obliged to unlearn all he taught me; my French maſter told me, I had been moſt execrably inſtructed.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: That he might ſay to anſwer ſome purpoſe of his own. Perhaps an Engliſh performer may not poſſeſs the ſpirit and brilliancy of a French one; but I have been told the latter are apt to neglect laying a ſolid foundation, which is the method our good maſters always obſerve.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I really kn • w nothing about the matter; and I never give myſelf the trouble to think: Monſieur de Brun was a very polite man, and always praiſed me.
sp.stage: [Maſter Vernon looking out of the window.]

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Here come our viſitors. Now, Cecilia, for ſome of your French airs and graces?

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I wiſh I could tranſport you to the antipodes; you are the moſt impertinent boy I ever knew.
sp.stage: [Enter the three young ladies; Miſs Selwyn advances to meet them with great politeneſs, and introduces them to Miſs Vernon.]

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Miſs Ward, Miſs Franklin, Miſs Thurot, need I name the lady to whom I am introducing you?

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Oui, certainment; Am I not entierement grown out of their knowledge?

sp.speaker: Miſs WARD.
sp.p: Miſs Vernon, I rejoice to ſee you.

sp.speaker: M ••• FRANKLIN.
sp.p: It is certainly your old playfellow! How glad I am you are returned home! [They advance and embrace her.]

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: Though I have not had the pleaſure of ſeeing you before, yet I am a ſharer with your other friends, Miſs Vernon, in the happineſs your return gives them, for I have heard you ſo frequently ſpoken of, that I longed to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Je ſuis ravi a ce moment, which once more unites me a mes belles amies, among whom I am rejoiced to reckon you [addreſſing Miſs Thurot.]

sp.speaker: Miſs WARD.
sp.p: How happy you muſt be to come home! La, my dear, was not a convent a deteſtible place? from what I have read and heard of them, I would not go to one for the world.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I cannot pretend to ſay it was bien charmant; but I ſhall now reap the advantage by having been educated in a ſuperior ſtyle.

sp.speaker: Miſs FRANKLIN.
sp.p: I doubt not your accompliſhments, Miſs Vernon. But you muſt be very clever indeed to exceed our dear Tereſa who is reckoned a perfect prodigy.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN. [bluſhing.]
sp.p: Pray do not beſtow ſuch undeſerved praiſes on me; I do not wiſh to vie with any one.

sp.speaker: Miſs WARD.
sp.p: Well, you are very clever to be ſure, at leaſt we are told ſo; but I think Miſs Vernon will be more to my taſte, ſhe ſeems ſo lively.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Me? je ſuis toujours gaie. I have overturned the heads of the whole family in the ſhort time ſince my return.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: It is time then you ſettled your own, for if you do not take care it will all drop off preſently.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I wiſh, ſir, you were gone to ſchool.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I dare ſay you do; and I ſhall be very ready to go, that I may entertain my ſchool-fellows with an imitation of ſome of your grimmaces.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I do not mind you, that is one comfort. What ſhall we do to divert ourſelves?

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: Any thing that is agreeable to theſe young ladies will be ſo to me. But I am ſo fond of muſic, that I ſhould prefer that entertainment to any other.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: My couſin, I hope, will not refuſe to begin.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I would rather hear ſomebody elſe firſt. That mad boy has agitated me I cannot ſing yet.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Then I will ſet the example in hope of having it followed, and that my playing may not appear to the diſadvantage it muſt do after hearing a better performer.

[Miſs Selwyn plays and ſings, during which time Miſs Thurot and Miſs Franklin, ſtand by her liſtening. Miſs Vernon and Miſs Ward whiſper and laugh. Maſter Vernon eyes them very archly; when it is over, Miſs Selwyn riſes.

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p:
You play enchantingly, Miſs Selwyn, I wiſh I could
perform as well, my papa would be delighted to hear you; he is amazingly lond of muſic, and very anxious for me to excel in it.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Indeed, couſin, you are a great proficient, and ſing a merveille!
sp.stage: [Maſter Vernon burſts into a loud laugh.]

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Pray how much did you hear of it? for you have been louder than the muſic.

sp.speaker: Miſs WARD.
sp.p: Come, Miſs Vernon, you muſt abſolutely play now. I am dying to hear you.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON [riſes with great affectation.]
sp.p: I will with pleaſure oblige you. [Takes a French ſang out of her pocket; then ſeats herſelf, and begins playing, during which ſhe throws herſelf into attitudes like foreigners. Soon after ſhe begins, Maſter Vernon, who has obſerved her ſometime, goes out, then returns with a • ooking glaſs, which he places ſuddenly before her.]

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: What is that for, ſir?

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: To ſhew you what a monkey is like. Why, I never ſaw any thing elſe like you.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: This is too much to ſubmit to, making me break off in the fineſt part of the ſong, and diſappointing the young ladies.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Do not make yourſelf uneaſy about that, I will entertain the ladies quite in your ſtile. [He imitates her action and manner of ſinging.]

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON, [burſts into tears.]
sp.p: I cannot ſubmit to ſuch cruel uſage. Why, if you muſt play ridiculous tricks, did you not chuſe Tereſa inſtead of me to make your ſubject?

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Becauſe ſhe did nothing ridiculous. Why, there was not one of your cheres amies, that did not laugh at you.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Inſufferable inſolence! I will complain to my mamma if you perſiſt in abuſing me.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Pray George, forbear, indeed you are wrong to diſtreſs your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: It is impoſſible I ſhould play, or do any thing elſe well whilſt he is ridiculing me.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: It is only owing to my ignorance. Conſider I never ſaw a frenchified belle before. Miſs Thurot was born in France, why does not ſhe behave like you if it is the faſhion of that nation?

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: No, ſir, I was born and educated in England, my parents were French.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Well then if it was right to ſqueeze about like my ſiſter, to be ſure your papa and mamma would have taught you to do it.

sp.speaker: Miſs WARD.
sp.p: Pray, Maſter Vernon, do not ſay any more, you quite ſpoil our amuſement. Come, let one of us play while the reſt dance.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: De tout mon coeur. I am now again ready for any thing lively.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall have the honor of dancing with every lady but my ſiſter. If ſhe dances as ſhe plays, I can never hope to poſſeſs perfection enough for her partner.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Who will begin?—Accept me as a fidler. [She fitſ down to the harpſichord and plays a minuet.]
[Maſter Vernon takes out Miſs Ward and Miſs Franklin, and dances alternately with them.]

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I am quite tired.—Come let the French ladies dance together.

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: If Miſs Vernon will accept an indifferent partner, I am at her ſervice.

[Whilſt they are ſettling themſelves, George ſlyly pins a cracker on the back of his ſiſter's gown; juſt as ſhe is doing the pas grave, at giving her ſecond hand, he contrives, by means of a lighted paper, to ſet fire to it, and it goes off with a great bounce; ſhe falls down in a fright, and all the reſt run about ſcreaming; he ſtands and laughs moſt violently.]

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Indeed, couſin George, you carry your jokes to a length infinitely beyond prudence; what have you done? my dear Cecilia ſuffer me to aſſiſt you in riſing, I hope you are not hurt.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: There is my grandmamma alarmed I dare ſay. What account, ſir, will you give of yourſelf to her?

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I ſhall not trouble myſelf to give her any. I never heard a cracker go off ſo well in my life. [Laughs and holds his ſides.]

div.stage: [Enter Sally.]

sp.speaker: SALLY.
sp.p: What is the matter in this room, ladies? my lady is exceſſively alarmed, and thinks ſome accident has happened.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: No perſon is hurt, Sally. The noiſe was owing to one of George's frolicks. Pray haſten to relieve my grandmamma's fears.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I wonder. Tereſa, you, who are ſo very attentive to your old adviſer, do not go and give her an account of every thing that is paſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: If any pleaſant circumſtance occurred, I ſhould certainly put myſelf forward to relate it; but in the preſent eaſe, ſilence is beſt. To ſpeak truth would pain her; and to utter falſhood, is meanneſs.

sp.speaker: Miſs WARD.
sp.p: Well, I ſee no harm in deceiving an old woman. I am ſure my grandmamma does not hear above one true word in ten from me; indeed, I do not trouble myſelf to talk much to her; for I hate to ſatisfy her tireſome queſtions.

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: I am ſurpriſed to hear you ſay ſo, for I think ſhe and Mrs. Vernon are the moſt pleaſing old ladies I ever ſaw, they always have ſuch a benignant ſmile, and are ſo condeſending to young people.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: The ſmiles of old women are, in my eyes, only ſneers. But it is the faſhion to look upon our old ladies as oracles, ſo we muſt ſubmit to the hearing them; but further than this, I cannot go.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Well, I own, there is ſomething ſo mild and good in my grandmamma's appearance, that when I am with her, I cannot help thinking ſhe is a being ſuperior to the generality of the world.

sp.speaker: Miſs FRANKLIN.
sp.p: And ſo ſhe is. I am ſure I hear her praiſed wherever I go; they ſay ſhe is both wiſe and good.

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: I declare, I am never ſo happy as when permitted to paſs a few hours with her, and always return home with ſome new ſentiments, collected from her converſation, that make me wiſer and better.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Well, ladies, I think you are rather on a dry ſubject. Have you no new plays?

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I bar every thing like play in your company. You have almoſt killed me with your evil tricks.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: So much the better; then you will never dance and ſing again.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Pray, George, recollect yourſelf; indeed, you forget that you ought to protect your ſiſter from inſolence, not make her the ſubject of it.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Well then, peace for ever, I proclaim it. Come, ſiſter▪ ſhake hands. I ſhould not have thought of doing what I have done, but to pleaſe and entertain you, becauſe you boaſted of having ſuch uncommon ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: And ſo I have, George, if I might be permitted to indulge them. I have not been in the garden yet ſince my return. and long to ſee the improvements.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: We had better then go immediately, or the evening will cloſe and prevent us; on our return tea will be ready▪

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I ſhall go and fly my kite then during your walk, for 〈◊〉 would by no means interrupt your agreeable converſation.

sp.speaker: Miſs WARD.
sp.p:
Do as you pleaſe, ſir; we are not ambitious of you •
company.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Pray do not begin with him, he ſeems inclined to 〈◊〉 quiet, and let us keep him ſo.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Your ſervant, ladies.

sp.speaker: Miſs FRANKLIN.
sp.p: Here are our calaſhes. I am ready.

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: So are we.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: We can take ours as we go through the hall.
sp.stage: [As they are going out, enter Sally.]

sp.speaker: SALLY.
sp.p: My lady deſires to ſee Miſs Selwyn, and one of the other young ladies.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Not me, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: SALLY.
sp.p: No Miſs, one of the viſitors.

sp.speaker: Miſs FRANKLIN.
sp.p: May I be indulged with the honor of accompanying you, Tereſa?

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: A little French quickneſs would have ſtood my friend now, for you are beforehand with me Amelia.

sp.speaker: Miſs WARD.
sp.p: Then you had better both go. Miſs Vernon and I are ready to excuſe you.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Allons done!—Come let us haſten, or it will be dark.

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: May I take the liberty of going with you to your grandmamma's apartment, Tereſa?

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: Undoubtedly; and you will make her very happy in your company.

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: Thus kindly encouraged, I cannot reſiſt the opportunity of enjoying ſo great a pleaſure.

div.head: SCENE, the Drawing-Room. The tea things ſet.
[Mrs. G. Vernon and Mrs. Selwyn.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: I HAVE ſent the dear girls in queſt of their companions, and when they return will make the 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: I am in no hurry. You are not well, daughter, I fear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: My mind, dear madam, is greatly diſturbed. [She burſts into tears.] The conſequence of my ſtrange infatuation have, I fear, quite changed the once gentle mind of my poor Cecilia.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: If you are convinced it wants correcting my fears abate; ſhe is young, and may yet be taught to overcome the prejudices of education, difficult as I fear the taſk may prove; but I own, I apprehended you would be as blind to her errors as you were to her intereſt, when you determined on giving her a foreign education.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: You know not, my dear mother, the miſery that I now experience, for having obſtinately perſevered in an opinion ſo fatal to my child. O! that I alone ſuffered! unhappy girl! my fatal impropriety has perverted her heart, and deprived her of thoſe finer feelings, which are the greateſt ornaments of the female mind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: Comfort yourſelf dear Louiſa, your daughter is not old in error; the very acquiſitions ſhe ſo much plumes herſelf upon, will only turn to her mortification. Introduce her among amiable people; their example will ſhew her the abſurdity of her own conceit, and teach her how trifling outward accompliſhments are, when unaccompanied by diffidence and modeſty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Nor will it be amiſs to let her ſometimes mix with young people as improperly educated as herſelf. The contraſt will be ſtriking, and more convincing than precept; ſhe muſt be led by gentleneſs, by attentively watching every turn of her mind, we may imperceptibly implant that ſolid virtue we wiſh to cultivate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p:
I ought not to deſpair
〈◊〉 I have ſuch kind and able aſſiſtants; but I do not deſerve, after my miſerable miſmanagement, the happineſs of ſeeing my daughter like her couſin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Subject as we all are to errors, it is our duty to excuſe them. Parents who love their children, certainly wiſh to fix on the propereſt mode of education, and ſuch as they think will lead them to the good they wiſh them to gain. But here the parent's mind betrays the child, and the worldly minded cannot expect ſuch bleſſed effects as generally reward thoſe who have a view to higher conſiderations.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: But I, madam, had better adviſers, and might have eſcaped the rock ſo plainly pointed out to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p:
You were young, and perhaps thought an old woman's advice the effect of age and ſpleen; but tha •
〈◊〉 paſt. Let us now endeavour to overcome what we could not prevent. You, Louiſa, muſt be the great actor: your daughter will not regard the •• monitions of her 〈◊〉 and me, unleſs they are ſupported 〈◊〉 you. The firſt thing, therefore, you have to determine on, is ſteadineſs; upon no account be led to ſmile, or encourage any of her lively ſallies, (as ſhe terms them,) which at beſt are only pe ••
neſs and ſ •• ppancy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p:
My ſiſter, who is ſo different herſelf, will not, I think, allow in Cecilia ſuch wretched meanneſs, by ſome called, wit, which conſiſts in ridiculing the worthy; ſome, becauſe they are old; others, becauſe they are grave; and
others, becauſe they are ugly; to ſuch perſons, an old face, a large noſe, a wide mouth, little eyes, &c. will furniſh ſubjects for mirth during a whole afternoon, to thoſe who do not conſider the wickedneſs of remarks which reflect on the divine hand that formed perſons with theſe imperfections, not on the unfortunate poſſeſſors of them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: Indeed, Charlotte, I deteſt ſuch kind of converſation as much as you can do; for it is totally inconſiſtent with that commendable ſenſibility which ought to make a part of the female character. Perſons who have a turn to this kind of ridicule, muſt either be inſenſibly thoughtleſs or elſe cruel and malicious.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Per •• leſs, in my opinion, is deteſtable. How often have I ſeen low ridicule put the worthy and the diffident out of countenance, while many ſtood ſmiling round, enjoying the jeſt, and the confuſion it produced.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: Upon thoſe occaſions frequently have I prayed, that my children might eſcape ſuch unworthy ſentiments; and now, by my mode of education, they ſeem to be the characteriſtic of them both.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: I am not alarmed on George's account; he has a great deal of good ſenſe under the roughneſs of a ſchool-boy; and I think, the ſcene that paſſed this afternoon, which Miſs Franklin really deſcribed in a very diverting manner, will be a mean of ſhewing Cecilia, the abſurdity of her conduct.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Certainly; while he ridiculed hiſ ſiſter's folly, he ſhewed a diſtinguiſhing mind, for he did not attempt ridiculing any of the other young ladies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: But ſurely he ought not to be encouraged in treating Cecilia with contempt, and making her the ſubject of mirth to himſelf and friends.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: Undoubtedly not; we muſt endeavour to convince him of this impropriety and teach him to correct it; but yet, his behaviour may be made a uſeful leſſon to his ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: I wiſh ſhe may be prevailed on to receive it as ſuch.—But alas! ſhe ſeems very little diſpoſed to avail herſelf of any mode of inſtruction.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p:
Let us hope the beſt my dear ſiſter. The follies we have this day obſerved in Cecilia, ſhew a perverted underſtanding, it muſt be owned, but do not prove that ſhe has a
• ad heart. I wiſh much to know whether ſhe has eſcaped perverſion in a very material point—I mean Religion.—The danger in this reſpect, has all along appeared to me ſo great, that I could never think of it without horror.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: It is a ſubject we muſt at leaſt for a time avoid talking upon to her, though of infinitely the greateſt conſequence; our own attention will ſoon enable us to make every requiſue obſervation, and inſtruct us in the beſt methods to purſue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: I ſhudder to reflect on what a precipice my beloved Cecilia ſtands. O, that my prayers may avail to avert this moſt poignant misfortune! I muſt enter upon the ſubject as ſoon as poſſible, for I am all anxiety to know what my child is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: Keep up your ſpirits, however my dear ſiſter; you muſt have all your thoughts about you, and endeavour to take the lead in every converſation at which Cecilia is preſent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p:
I will certainly follow your advice, and ſtudy to retrieve my paſt errors. Wonderful! that I ſhould perſiſt for ſeven years in one which deprived me of my greateſt joy and comfort; for never mother loved a child more than I do my Cecilia; and, but for what I thought her advantage, ſhe ſhould never have been out of my ſight. Often have I envied you, ſiſter, in having Tere • a
with you, and ſhould certainly have ſent for my daughter, but that a falſe ſhame reſtrained me from it; though I always dreaded, as much as longed, for her teturn.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: I think, daughter, the expence of education abroad is nearly as much as at home; and if ſo, what reaſon can there be for baniſhing a child ſo many years?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: Indeed, madam, Cecilia's education has coſt me even more than it would have done in England. The firſt year the demands for it were moderate, and according to the agreement I made; but they have increaſed ſince more that I wiſh to own; for this confeſſion only adds to the inexcufeableneſs of my conduct. The ſuperior of the convent, ſolemnly engaged to leave her free in reſpect to religion; but diſappointed as I am in other reſpects, I can have little hopes that her mind remains untainted in this particular.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN [moves to the tea table.]
sp.p: I hear the voices of the young people, and will therefore prepare for them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Do, my dear, perhaps during tea we may draw from Cecilia opinions that will inſtruct us for our future proceedings.

div.stage: [Enter Miſs Selwyn, Miſs Franklin, and Miſs Thurot.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: Are you come alone, ladies?

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: We could not find my couſin and Miſs Ward; but as we entered the houſe heard their voices and George's very loud by the filbert hedge.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: They are coming. I hear a ſtrange noiſe.
sp.stage: [Enter Maſter Vernon with a handful of falſe hair in one hand, dragging in his ſiſter with the other, her cap off, her curlſ unpinned, and hanging about her ears, and ſhe in tears, Miſs Ward follows taking her part.]
sp.p: Master Vernon [laughing, and holding up the falſe hair.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Look here! I have found her out! I knew, all that immenſe head could not belong to one perſon.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Am I not to find protection any where? reſcue me, I beſeech you, dear mamma, from this cruel boy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON [ſeparates them.]
sp.p: For ſhame, George, is this the treatment due from a brother to a ſiſter? you who ſhould protect her from the inſolence of others, inſtead of ſetting ſuch an example. What would your wortly father ſay, if he could look out of his grave, and ſee his representative acting ſo differently from what he himſelf would do?

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I did not mean to hurt her, but ſhe would not own her having falſe hair, ſo I was determined to find it out, and I diſcovered her nicely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: It is in vain to reaſon with you, ſir; but you ſhall go to ſchool to-morrow, and never come home till you have learnt to behave with more propriety. Your ſiſter's foibles, however great, ought not to be ſubjects for ridicule, but pity, to her neareſt relations.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Well, I am ſure, ſhe ſpares none of her relations; for they all have their turn to be laughed at.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: I am ſorry to hear ſhe is capable of ſo much giddineſs. If ſhe did ſet you the example, George, ſhe has ſuffered ſufficiently for it and I am concerned; to find that as you had diſcernment enough to diſtinguiſh how unamiable it was in her, you had not ſufficient prudence to prevent your falling into the 〈◊〉 error. [During this converſation, the young ladies adjuſt Miſs Vernon's dreſs.]

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I am ſure my brother has tormented me ever ſince I entered this house. I think it is very hard I cannot find peace at home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: Indeed it is, my poor Cecilia; nor can I think you could deſerve ſuch treatment by any expreſſions of your own.

sp.speaker: Miss VERNON, [looks aſhamed.]
sp.p: Whatever I have ſaid, aunt, was only in jeſt.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Well it was the ſame with me. I meant no harm, only a little diverſion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: You have both been extremely to blame; and your puniſhment, Cecilia, though inflicted by a wrong person, is ſuch as may ſhew you the impropriety of that low mean opinion, which leads you, when in the ridiculing vein, to ſpare neither friend nor relation.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: It is very hard, mamma, that I muſt not ſpeak a word, but my brother will repeat it to my diſadvantage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: Say nothing improper, and you need not fear a repetition of it. Do by others as you would have them do by you, and you will no longer be guilty of a fault that muſt tender your company unpleaſant to every one.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: La! mamma, one cannot be expected to think at my age as you do. I often ſpeak without any meaning at all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: And by that mean wound where you ſhould be kind. The tricks your brother has played you he did unthinkingly; yet you do not accept that excuſe from him as a compenſation.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: No, certainly, becauſe he hurt me, and made me appear abſurd, before company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Yet you can with pleaſure, by flippancy, put the modeſt out of countenance, merely becauſe they are without the ſame talents to retort.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: I never thought about it before, nor was I ever corrected upon the ſubject, but was alwayſ encouraged by my companions to make them laugh.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: You have more excuſe than any of theſe young ladies could have for the ſame ſault, becauſe you have been deprived of good adviſers; but I hope to convince you, how very disagreeable ſuch kind of low wit muſt render you.
[Miſs Ward appears confuſed.]

sp.speaker: Miſſ VERNON.
sp.p: But you will allow grandmamma, that the natural fiveliness of young people may ſometimes lead them to ſay and do things they ought not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: I make every allowance for the inexperience and volatility of youth; but when a fault proceeds from an unfeeling heart, it is, in my eyes, unpardonable; and I have no idea that a perſon of a good diſpoſition can, at any age, take pleaſure in putting another out of countenance, merely for thinking they have said a good thing. As one of my favorite author's ſays, Young's Univerſal Paſſion,

l.hi: "Who for the poor renown of being ſmart,
"Would leave a ſting within another's heart?"

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: George, give the ladies their tea; you ſhall wait upon us this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I am very happy to be employed; and what is more, I am ſorry for my behaviour to my ſiſter, and will never act ſo again to any one. I had no deſign to be ill-natured, though it appeared that I had. [He goes to her, and takes her hand very affectionately.] Come Cecilia, you muſt forgive me.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Moſt cordially, George, and I thank you for your excuſes. I am quite aſhamed of my own conduct, which drew upon me your cenſure.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Indeed, Cecilia, without a jeſt, you do not appear half ſo well as theſe other young ladles. I ſhould not find fault with you if you were like them.

sp.speaker: Miss VERNON.
sp.p: Well, ſir, you need not begin again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON, [interrupting her.]
sp.p: Now I muſt take my ſon's part. He has indeed given you moſt excellent advice. Your ſpirits appear aſſumed and not natural. Some young people are livelier than others; and, when it is the bent of their diſpoſitions, their livelineſs is very pleaſing; but you Cecilia, when a child were always grave; your preſent mode of conduct does not, therefore, ſit eaſy upon you.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON. [after a pauſe.]
sp.p: My dear mamma, I will confeſs my inward mind to you. I was ſo unhappy in the convent, that had I not aſſumed this frivolous manner of behaviour I ſhould have fretted myſelf to death. You were too diſtant to hear my complaints. I was not permitted to write to you. Habit familiariſed nonſenſe; and I thought it right on my return to appear as I had done abroad, that I might be unlike every one bred in England. I ſhall endeavour to reſume my natural temper, though your inſtruction will be neceſſary to remind me when I forget myſelf.
Mrs. G. Vernon [looks delighted, and takes her hand.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: With pleaſure I accept the office you appoint, and will be your monitor on all neceſſary occaſions.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Come, and let me embrace my beloved child, the dear offspring of an excellent ſon. Your laſt speech has given me a joy I little expected to feel from your late appearance. [They embrace and ſhed tears.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: I too muſt ſhare theſe careſſes, and tell my dear Cecilia, I love her with a mother's fondneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: Had you been her mother ſhe would not have been thrown on ſuch rocks as I placed in her way; but ſhe is reſcued from them, for which I return my unfeigned thanks where due.

sp.speaker: Miſs SELWYN.
sp.p: I hope my dear conſin, you will now love me as well as ever, and let us henceforth be friends and ſiſters.

sp.speaker: Miſs VRENON.
sp.p: That I will, my dear Tereſa, and with joy accept your kind invitation; though I own, with bluſhes, the hope of out-doing you, made me purchaſe that falſe hair which produced my ſhame, and now my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Miſs WARD.
sp.p: Do not blame yourſelf, or your education too 〈◊〉 dear Miſs Vernon, ſince you are kindly pardoned. I have always practiſed the ſame flippancy; but from this moment will endeavour to diveſt myſelf of it, and will never treat my grandmamma improperly again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: An excellent reſolution my dear, and I doubt not your keeping it. We wil • have the tea equipage removed, and then proceed to ſomething more like amuſen ••• than the paſt converſation has been. [The bell is rung, a footman enters, and goes out with the tea things.

sp.speaker: Miſs FRANKLI • .
sp.p: I cannot wiſh for any entertainment that deprives us of the inſtruction which the converſation of the preſent company, always conveys, in which I learn ſentiments I hope never to forget.

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: I always lament loſing a moment which might be ſo well ſpent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: You are very polite young ladies, with ſuch a diſpoſition your ſociety will be deſirable to people of all ages. But there is time for all things. Youth is the ſeaſon for gaiety; enjoy it properly, only act with diſcretion; then you may look forward to a peaceable old age, unembittered by regret for miſpent time.

sp.speaker: Miſs THUROT.
sp.p: Pray, Miſs Vernon, did you go to m • ſs?

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Not conſtantly; but I ſometimes went, and was forced to attend all hours of devotion in the convent, except in the night, thoſe I waſ excuſed from.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON, [in an agitation.]
sp.p: And how did you like it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON, [in an agitation.]
sp.p: 〈◊〉 how did you like it?

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p:
I was pleaſed with the ſolemnity of their worſhip; and ſtill I muſt confeſs, my dear mamma, that I rather feel a bias towards a religion which, notwithſtanding the promiſes that were made to you to the contrary, thoſe who had the care of my education took ſo much pains to inculcate; and had it not been for the urgent deſire I felt • o return to England, I certainly ſhould have profeſſed myſelf a Roman Catholic; but I knew I ſhould by thiſ mean cut myſelf off from my family and deareſt connections, therefore, reſolved to reſiſt all importunities; and the levity of conduct which I aſſumed, (though highly blameable) was thus far ſerviceable to me, that it ſelt me little time to attend to any ſerious ſubject; for, except during the time of divine ſervice, and whilſt I was re
•• iving grave lectures, I ſeldom thought on religion at all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: What a fortunate eſcape have you had. Oh, how my heart reproaches me for the danger I have expoſed you to!

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Do not, my dear daughter, afflict yourſelf too much for an error, which, I truſt, is not irreparable. I hope, from the compariſon which Cecilia, now ſhe is of an age to diſtinguiſh, will be able to make between our rational ſervice and the unmeaning pageantry of the Romiſh Church, ſhe will eaſily incline to give preference to the former; and that we ſhall be able to eradicate the falſe prejudices ſhe has unhappily imbibed.

sp.speaker: Miſs VERNON.
sp.p: Indeed, my dear grandmamma, I will with pleaſure attend to the inſtructions of you and the reſt of my good friends.—I am very ignorant, but I yield myſelf to your guidance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Your friends will have pleaſure in the taſk; and I am thankful that you have but little more than ignorance to overcome. How much worſe might it not have been?

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p:
In the 〈◊〉 of my bitter regret, a happy proſpect perſents
itſelf before me. Your advice, dear mother ſhall in future have its due influence with me, and, I hope wi • h mine; and may Heaven great you length of days for your comfort!

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Whilſt my life is ſpared, I wiſh to make is aſ uſeful as poſſible. But, whenever I go, there is no fear but your good ſenſe, which enables you to perceive your late error, will keep you in the path you ſhould tread in, as much for your own ſake, aſ for theſe dear children's whoſe guide you muſt be.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: I do not know what ails me, but I am ready to • ry; and am ſorry for having been at times ſo pert to all my relations.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: Well ſaid, my dear boy, a fault handſomely acknowledged claims forgiveneſs, and I doubt not, your proving as great a comfort to us all as our beloved Cecilia.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Thank you aunt, for your good opinion. Deſire mamma to let me have two or three holidays, and I will not for a long time intrude on her goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: Upon that condition I grant your requeſt; I like to indulge you, George, but muſt keep you more ſtrictly to your learning, for I fear coming home ſo often has interfered with your Greek and Latin.

sp.speaker: Maſter VERNON.
sp.p: Not very much, mamma. But, indeed, I will take more pains in •• uture.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: By way of compoſing our ſpirits, what ſay you to a few minutes? our footman plays a decent fiddle; he is in the hall.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: I am obliged to you for the propoſal, ſiſter, and hope my dear mother will give the young people an applauding ſmile.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: With pleaſure. Only to avoid catching cold I will ſit in my little parlour and look through the glaſs door at them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p:
Go then, my dears, and ſee that every thing is in readineſs,
and deſire John to roſin his bow, for I think you will exerciſe it. [The young people all go out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: What an undeſervedly happy woman am I! and how has this bleſt hour relieved my heart from agony too great to be long endured!

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Your future attention to your children's welfare will, I hope, enfure you a continuance of your preſent happy proſpects, and bleſs us in their riſing virtues.

sp.speaker: Mrs. SELWYN.
sp.p: We ought with heart-felt thankfulneſs to acknowledge, that all our preſent comfort ariſes from the over-ruling hand of Providence; which alone preſerved our dear child from abſolute perverſion. But let not any parent be encouraged from hence to expoſe theirs to the ſame temptation, as they cannot know what the event may be.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: Though this dear child had not been entirely neglected in her infancy from an idea of her being too young to receive religious inſtructions, yet what might have become of her when tranſported into a foreign land, before any good principle • iad taken root in her mind?

div.stage: [Enter a Footman.]

sp.speaker: FOOTMAN.
sp.p: Every thing is ready madam, and the ladies beg me tell you they are impatient to begin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. G. VERNON.
sp.p: We will attend them immediately. [Footman goes out.] Come, dear mother and ſiſter, let me lead you to a ſcene of innocent feſtivity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. VERNON.
sp.p: With inexpreſſible delight do I accompany you, and am thankful that I have lived to ſee this day, in which my family are again collected, and my fears for one dear branch of it happily removed.
